[[File:Plaque commemorating the 1984 Abbeystead Explosion - geograph.org.uk - 514373.jpg|thumb|right|Plaque commemorating those who died in the explosion, situated outside the Valve house]] The '''Abbeystead disaster''' occurred on the evening of 23 May 1984 when a [[methane]] gas explosion destroyed a waterworks' [[pumping station|valve house]] at [[Abbeystead]], [[Lancashire]], [[England]].<ref name="hse">{{cite book|title=The Abbeystead Explosion: a report of the investigation by the Health and Safety Executive into the explosion on 23 May 1984 at the valve house of the Lune/Wyre Water Transfer Scheme at Abbeystead|author=HSE|authorlink=Health and Safety Executive|isbn=0-11-883795-8|year=1985}}</ref> A group of 44 visitors was inside the underground building at the time attending a public presentation by [[North West Water|North West Water Authority]] (NWWA) to demonstrate the operations of the station. Eight were killed instantly by the explosion, and the others were severely injured.<ref name=hse /> The explosion also caused the concrete roof to fall down on to the group, destroying the steel mesh floor and throwing some of the victims into the water chambers below which rapidly filled with river water.<ref name=hse /> Another eight people subsequently died of their injuries in hospital. An 11-year-old boy and his mother were among the dead. The official inquiry into the disaster concluded that the methane had seeped from coal deposits 3,937 feet (1,200 m) below ground and had built up in an empty pipeline.<ref name="balmer">{{cite web|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/runner-up-richard-balmers-account-of-the-abbeystead-explosion/756249.article|title=Abbeystead explosion|work=[[New Civil Engineer]]|first=Richard|last=Balmer|date=20 February 2008|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref> The gas was then ejected into the valve house by the sudden pressure of water as the pumps were switched on.<ref name="new">{{cite journal|title=Blowing the roof off Abbeystead|first=Fred|last=Pearce|date=23 May 1985|journal=[[New Scientist]]|issue=1457|issn=0028-6664|location=London|pages=28–32}}</ref> The cause of ignition has never been determined.<ref name=hse />
==Background== The Abbeystead valve house was constructed as part of NWWA's 'Lancashire conjunctive use scheme,' a water supply project "to help in meeting the region's expected increases in water demand during the 1980s." The scheme involved the daily extraction of up to {{convert|62|e6impgal|m3}} of water from the [[River Lune]] near [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]] which was then pumped through Abbeystead into the [[River Wyre]]. From here it would be extracted to a treatment works to augment the drinking water supply for south Lancashire.<ref name=seton/>
==Explosion== The visitors were from the village of [[St Michael's on Wyre|St. Michael's on Wyre]], situated approximately 10 miles from the valve house and which had previously suffered flooding which residents believed was caused by the station pumping water from the River Lune to the River Wyre. The tour of the valve house had been arranged by NWWA to alleviate public concern about the flooding.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|date=24 May 1984|location=London|page=1|issue=61839|title=Explosion kills six during villagers' water plant visit}}</ref> George Mann, chairman of NWWA, said that the tour was intended to have a "family flavour."<ref name="seton">{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=25 May 1984|page=1|issue=61840|title=Lethal build-up of methane gas blamed for Abbeystead disaster|first1=Craig|last1=Seton|first2=Robin|last2=Young}}</ref> The tour commenced at 7.20pm and the explosion occurred approximately 10 minutes later, with the first telephone call to the emergency services logged at 7.37pm.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=25 May 1984|page=1|issue=61840|title=The roofless chamber of death; A stunned village flies its flag at half mast|first=Ronald|last=Faux}}</ref> Oliver Chippendale, the supervisor of a pumping station on the River Lune had received a telephone call from George Lacey, the NWWA district manager conducting the tour, asking him to commence pumping, and a second call 5 minutes later saying that no water was coming through and to activate a second, larger, pump. Twenty minutes later Chippendale called Abbeystead to check water was coming through and the telephone was answered by water engineer John Nelson who shouted "Get help! There has been a terrible disaster!"<ref name=seton/> The force of the blast had lifted 30 concrete roof beams, each weighing 2½ tons, upwards through the soil landscaping above them before they fell into the chamber below.
Independent geological and seismic surveys commissioned by NWWA later identified the source of the methane gas as coal seams 3,937 feet (1,200 m) below the pipeline. The gas had collected over millions of years in a natural limestone reservoir, from which it seeped towards the surface through a complex network of geological faults. The cutting of the tunnel had intersected these faults and allowed the gas to seep in through its concrete lining.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Source of Abbeystead blast found|first=Peter|last=Davenport|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=11 March 1986|page=3}}</ref>
==Inquest== An [[inquest]] into the deaths was held at Lancaster in October 1984. The jury returned a majority verdict of [[accidental death]] on all 16 victims.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=31 October 1984|page=3|issue=61974|title=Abbeystead witness tells of blast and victims with hair and clothes burnt off}}</ref>
The [[Health and Safety Executive]] investigated this incident and produced a special report in accordance with the [[Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974]].<ref>The Abbeystead Explosion. A report of the investigation by the Health and Safety Executive into the explosion on 23 May 1984 at the valve house of the Lune/Wyre Water Transfer Scheme at Abbeystead, Health and Safety Executive, 1985: [http://www.icheme.org/Abbeystead.pdf]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Liability== In March 1987, at [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster High Court]], the building's designers Binnie & Partners were found to be 55 per cent liable in negligence for failing to exercise "reasonable care" in assessing the risk of methane. NWWA was found to be 30 per cent to blame for failing to ensure the plant was safe for visitors and employees by testing for methane and Nuttall's Ltd., who constructed the works, were found 15 per cent liable for failing to carry out systematic tests for methane.<ref>{{cite news|title=Abbeystead disaster – 20 years on|work=The Visitor|location=Morecambe|date=19 May 2004}}</ref> All three appealed, and ultimately Binnie & Partners were found solely liable. Leave to appeal to the [[House of Lords]] was refused.<ref name="appeal">TE Eckersley and Others v Binnie & Partners and Others [1988] CILL 388</ref> In February 1989 most of the injured survivors and relatives of those who died accepted out-of-court settlements from Binnie & Partners.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Abbeystead victims to get £2.5m payout|last=Morris|first=Michael|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=10 February 1989|page=2}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Firedamp]]
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
{{coord|53.9788|-2.6804|type:event_region:GB|display=title}}

{{for|cables running to an aerial|Antenna (radio)}} {{redirect|Air cable|subscription television via wireless|Pay television}}
An '''aerial cable''' or '''air cable''' is an insulated cable usually containing all [[Electrical conductor|conductor]]s required for an electrical distribution system (typically using [[aerial bundled cable]]s) or a telecommunication line, which is suspended between [[utility pole]]s or [[electricity pylon]]s. As aerial cables are completely insulated there is no danger of [[electric shock]] when touching them and there is no requirement for mounting them with [[Insulator (electricity)|insulators]] on pylons and poles. A further advantage is they require less right of way than overhead lines for the same reason. They can be designed as [[shielded cable]]s for telecommunication purposes. If the cable falls, it may still operate if its insulation is not damaged.
As aerial cables are installed on pylons or poles, they may be cheaper to install than [[undergrounding|underground cable]]s, as no work for digging is required, which can be very expensive in rocky areas.
== Use == Aerial cables are mostly used for telecommunication systems or for power transmissions with voltages below 1000 volts. Aerial cable for voltages up to 69,000 volts has also been built, for the supply of farms, waterworks, transmitters and other facilities outside of urban areas. Aerial cables are not often used in transmission circuits because of the difficulty in insulating such high voltage wire. Because of the proven reliability benefits of insulated aerial cables over traditional air-insulated wire, the Electric Power Institute has been working with utility companies to develop better insulating materials. In 1996 they were able to successfully convert one lower-voltage transmission circuit to insulated cable. <ref>http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/756159/</ref>
== See also == * [[Aerial insert]] * [[Overhead power line]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{taxobox | image = Awarra-Small.jpg | image_caption = ''Atrocaryum vulgare'' | regnum = [[Plantae]] | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] | unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] | unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] | ordo = [[Arecales]] | familia = [[Arecaceae]] | genus = ''[[Astrocaryum]]'' | species = '''''A. vulgare''''' | binomial = ''Astrocaryum vulgare'' | binomial_authority = [[Mart.]] | synonyms = * ''Astrocaryum awarra'' Vriese * ''Astrocaryum guianense'' Splig. ex Mart. * ''Astrocaryum segregatum'' Drupe * ''Astrocaryum tucuma'' Wallace * ''Astrocaryum tucumoides'' Drupe |}}
'''''Astrocaryum vulgare''''' ([[common name]]s Tucum or Tucumã-do-Pará in [[Brazil]], Awara and wara in [[French Guiana]], Wara awara in [[Guyana]], awarra in [[Suriname]], Chontilla in [[Ecuador]]) is a [[Arecaceae|palm]] native to [[Amazon Rainforest]] [[List of plants of Amazon Rainforest vegetation of Brazil|vegetation]], typical of the [[Pará]] state in Brazil. This plant has [[Eating|edible]] [[fruit]], which are also used for [[biodiesel]] production. This plant is cited in ''[[Flora Brasiliensis]]'' by [[Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius]]. This species is native to the Amazonian region, possibly to the state of Pará, where it has its center of distribution, and reaches French Guiana and Suriname. It is a characteristic palm of terra firme, low vegetation cover, or even open fields. The tree is 10 to 15 m in height and regenerates easily by growing multiple stems. The tucumã palm is considered a pioneer plant of aggressive growth, has the ability to grow new shoots after a fire, and mainly inhabits secondary forests and pastures. Seeds take up to 2 years to germinate, the plants grow slowly in cultivation, and start to produce fruits after eight years. Its resistance to diseases and high productivity make this species an alternative for the production of biodiesel, since the operating costs of an orderly plantation is much less than that of the oil palm.<ref name="Morais">Morais, Luiz Roberto Barbosa Química de oleaginosas : valorização da biodiversidade amazônica = Chemistry of vegetable oils : valorization of the amazon biodiversity. — Belém, PA : Ed. do Autor, 2012. — (Oleaginosas). CDD-633.850981</ref> [[File:Awarra-Small.jpg|thumb|Awarra-Small|Astrocaryum vulgare palm]]
The seed is covered externally with an orange oily pulp. On average, the fruit weighs 30 g; 34% of this weight corresponds to the external pulp that has 14% to 16% of the oil when it is raw. A mature tree can produce up to 50 kg of fruits per year (25 kg per tree on average), which corresponds to 2.5 kg of pulp oil and 1.5 kg of seed oil. In one hectare, 400 palm clusters can be planted, each cluster with three trunks. In total, this equals 1200 palm trunks and will result in 4.8 tons of fatty material per hectare. It forms clusters that do not need to be replanted.<ref name="Morais"/>
==Oil==
The fruit is composed of a woody core almost black in color, containing a white almond paste, oilseed, very hard and covered with a yellow-orange pulp, little consistency and oily. Two types of oils are produced by this fruit: the oil of external pulp and almond oil. The oil is found in the fruit, as follows.<ref>PESCE, Celestino. Oleaginosas da Amazônia. –Belém: Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, 2009.334 p.: il. {{ISBN|978-85-61377-06-9}} (MPEG) e 978-85-60548-39-2 (MDA).</ref> [[File:Tucuma-oleo-frut4.JPG|thumb|Oil from the Tucumã pulp|Astrocaryum vulgare (Tucumã) oil]]
==Cuisine==
In [[French Guiana]], at Easter, Guianans eat a traditional dish made with awara dough called [[Awara broth]].
==The tucum ring== {{Main|Tucum ring}}
The seed in the fruit is notably used by [[Amazonian indian|indigenous Amazonians]] to make black [[Ring (jewellery)|rings]]. In the 1800s, this ring was used as a symbol of marriage for the slaves and natives, who could not afford to purchase gold. In addition, the ring was also a symbol of friendship and of resistance to the established order – the freedom fighters. Now these rings are worn by [[Catholic]] [[Missionaries#Catholic missions|missionaries]] as a symbol of solidarity with the poor and support in the struggle for equality, [[social justice]] and [[human rights]].<ref>[http://www.wordmadeflesh.org/brazil/2009/03/story-of-the-tucum-ring/ Story of the Tucum ring « Brazil<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090404090841/http://www.wordmadeflesh.org/brazil/2009/03/story-of-the-tucum-ring/ |date=April 4, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0iJKVjWes7g 'O Anel De Tucum'] (1994) Conrado Berning, 70 mins in Português,[http://www.verbofilmes.org.br/index.php?page=shop.product_details&flypage=flypage.tpl&product_id=63&category_id=22&keyword=anel&option=com_virtuemart&Itemid=79 Verbo Filmes]</ref><ref>Eneida Duarte Gaspar 'O Caminho da cruz' 2001 ({{ISBN|8534702969}})</ref><ref>[http://en.tucum.org/site/2493/nota/154498 en.tucum.org - Ceará’s Community Tourism Network receives the To Do! Award in Berlin<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128020144/http://en.tucum.org/site/2493/nota/154498 |date=November 28, 2010 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.askmotherrose.org/history/ring.htm our ring<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725021353/http://www.askmotherrose.org/history/ring.htm |date=July 25, 2011 }}</ref>
<gallery> Astrocaryum vulgare.jpg |Fruits of ''Astrocaryum vulgare'' Astrocaryum vulgare MHNT.jpg|Seeds </gallery>
==References== <references/> *Schultes, Richard E. (1974). Palms and religion in the northwest Amazon. ''[[Principes (botany)|Principes]]'' 18 (1): 3-21. *{{pt icon}} Freitas, C. O.; Silva, M. M., Silva, I. Q., Rodrigues, A. M. C. [ ''Características Físicas da Oleaginosa Tucumã'' (''Astrocaryum vulgare'' Mart.)]

{{short description|Strucural fibres spun from melted basalt}} '''Basalt fiber ''' is a material made from extremely fine [[fiber]]s of [[basalt]], which is composed of the [[mineral]]s [[plagioclase]], [[pyroxene]], and [[olivine]]. It is similar to [[fiberglass]], having better physicomechanical properties than fiberglass, but being significantly cheaper than carbon fiber. It is used as a [[Fireproofing|fireproof]] [[textile]] in the [[aerospace]] and [[automotive]] industries and can also be used as a [[Composite material|composite]] to produce products such as [[Tripod (photography)|camera tripods]]. ==Manufacture== The technology of production of BNV{{clarify|reason=The only non-wikipedia-circular reference to BNV I can find is for "Basalt from Nevada, USA (NV)", which would not require manufacturing.|date=August 2018}} is a one-stage process: melting, homogenization of basalt and extraction of fibers. Basalt is heated only once, which allows you to get the desired product: BNV. Further processing of BNV into materials is carried out using "cold technologies" with low energy costs. Basalt fiber is made from a single material, crushed basalt, from a carefully chosen quarry source.{{Cite news|url=http://basalt.pro/activities/materials/|title=Research surveys for basalt rock quarries {{!}} Basalt Projects Inc. {{!}} Engineering continuous basalt fiber and CBF-based composites|work=Basalt Projects Inc.|access-date=2017-12-10}} Basalt of high acidity (over 46% silica contenthttp://www.enea.it/it/pubblicazioni/EAI/anno-2011/indice-world-view-3-2011/basalt-fiber-from-earth-an-ancient-material-for-innovative-and-modern-application) and low iron content is considered desirable for fiber production.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ptonline.com/articles/composites-higher-properties-lower-cost|title=Composites: Higher Properties, Lower Cost|last=Schut|first=Jan H.|website=www.ptonline.com|access-date=2017-12-10}} Unlike with other composites, such as glass fiber, essentially no materials are added during its production. The basalt is simply washed and then melted.{{Cite web|url=http://www.compositesworld.com/articles/basalt-fibers-alternative-to-glass|title=Basalt Fibers: Alternative To Glass?|last=Ross|first=Anne|website=www.compositesworld.com|access-date=2017-12-10}} The manufacture of basalt fiber requires the melting of the crushed and washed basalt rock at about {{convert|1500|°C|°F}}. The molten rock is then [[Extrusion|extruded]] through small nozzles to produce continuous filaments of basalt fiber. The basalt fibers typically have a filament diameter of between 10 and 20 [[micrometre|µm]] which is far enough above the respiratory limit of 5 µm to make basalt fiber a suitable replacement for [[asbestos]]{{Cite web|url=https://basalt-fiber.com/|title=Basalt Fibers from continuous-filament basalt rock|last=|first=|date=|website=basalt-fiber.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. They also have a high [[elastic modulus]], resulting in excellent [[specific strength]]—three times that of [[steel]]{{Cite web|url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/82815068.pdf|title=Mechanical behavior of basalt fibers in a basalt-UP composite|last=B. Soares, R. Preto, L.Sousaa, L. Reisa|first=|date=February 2016|website=ScienceDirect|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/291516479|title=AN INTRODUCTION TO BASALT ROCK FIBER AND COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF ENGINEERING PROPERTIES OF BRF AND OTHER NATURAL COMPOSITES|last=Sharma|first=Piyush|date=January 2016|website=ResearchGate|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite journal|title=Bonding Properties of Basalt Fiber and Strength Reduction According to Fiber Orientation|journal = Materials|volume = 8|issue = 10|pages = 6719–6727|last=Jeong-Il Choi and Bang Yeon Lee|first=|date=October 2015|pmc = 5455386|pmid = 28793595|doi = 10.3390/ma8105335|bibcode = 2015Mate....8.6719C}}. Thin fiber is usually used for textile applications mainly for production of woven fabric. Thicker fiber is used in filament winding, for example, for production of CNG cylinders or pipes. The thickest fiber is used for pultrusion, geogrid, UD, multiaxial fabric production and in form of chopped strand for concrete reinforcement. One of the most prospective applications for continuous basalt fiber and the most modern trend at the moment is production of basalt rebar that more and more substitutes traditional steel rebar on construction market.{{Cite web|url=http://novitsky1.narod.ru/basalt_fiber.technology.html|title=Some aspects of the technological process of continuous basalt fiber|website=novitsky1.narod.ru|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-21}} ==Properties== The table refers to the continuous basalt fiber specific producer. Data from all the manufacturers are different, the difference is sometimes very large values. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Property !! Value{{cite web |url=http://www.albarrie.com/techfabrics/continuousfiber.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mO840Mwq?url=http://www.albarrie.com/techfabrics/continuousfiber.aspx |archivedate=2009-12-29 |df= }} |- | Tensile strength || 2.8–3.1 GPa |- | Elastic modulus || 85–87 GPa |- | Elongation at break || 3.15% |- | Density || 2.67 g/cm³ |} Comparison: {| class = "wikitable sortable" |- ! modulus]] |- | [[Steel re-bar]] || 7.85 || 0.5 || 0.0667 || 210 || 26.7 |- | [[A-glass]] || 2.46 || 2.1 || 1.35 || 69 || 28.0 |- | [[C-glass]] || 2.46 || 2.5 || 1.35 || 69 || 28.0 |- | [[E-glass]] || 2.60 || 2.5 || 1.33 || 76 || 29.2 |- | [[S-2 glass]] || 2.49 || 4.83 || 1.94 || 97 || 39.0 |- | [[Silicon]] || 2.16 || 0.206–0.412 || 0.0954–0.191 || || |- | [[Quartz]] || 2.2 || 0.3438 || 0.156 || || |- | [[Carbon fiber]] (large) || 1.74 || 3.62 || 2.08 || 228 || 131 |- | [[Carbon fiber]] (medium) || 1.80 || 5.10 || 2.83 || 241 || 134 |- | [[Carbon fiber]] (small) || 1.80 || 6.21 || 3.45 || 297 || 165 |- | [[Kevlar]] K-29 || 1.44 || 3.62 || 2.51 || 41.4 || 28.8 |- | [[Kevlar]] K-149 || 1.47 || 3.48 || 2.37 || || |- | [[Polypropylene]] || 0.91 || 0.27-0.65 || 0.297–0.714 || 38 || 41.7 |- | [[Polyacrylonitrile]] || 1.18 || 0.50-0.91 || 0.424–0.771 || 75 || 63.6 |- style="font-weight:bold;" | Basalt fiber || 2.65 || 2.9–3.1 || 1.57–1.81 || 85–87 || 32–33 |} {{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} {| !Material type{{Cite journal|doi = 10.1016/j.compstruct.2016.01.014|title = 3D finite element modeling of bond-controlled behavior of steel and basalt FRP-reinforced concrete square bridge columns under lateral loading|journal = Composite Structures|volume = 143|pages = 33–52|year = 2016|last1 = Ibrahim|first1 = Arafa M.A|last2 = Fahmy|first2 = Mohamed F.M|last3 = Wu|first3 = Zhishen}}!!Elastic modulus!!Yield stress!!Tensile strength |- |E (GPa)||fy (MPa)||fu (MPa) |- |13-mm-diameter steel bars||200||375||560 |- |10-mm-diameter steel bars||200||360||550 |- |6-mm-diameter steel bars||200||400||625 |- |10-mm-diameter BFRP bars||48.1||-||1113 |- |6-mm-diameter BFRP bars||47.5||-||1345 |- |BFRP sheet||91||-||2100 |} ==History== The first attempts to produce basalt fiber were made in the [[United States]] in 1923 by Paul Dhe who was granted {{US patent|1,462,446}}. These were further developed after [[World War II]] by researchers in the USA, [[Europe]] and the [[Soviet Union]] especially for [[military]] and aerospace applications. Since declassification in 1995 basalt fibers have been used in a wider range of civilian applications.{{Cite web|url=http://basfiber.com|title=Basalt fiber|website=basfiber.com|language=ru, en, de, ko, ja|access-date=2018-06-21}} ===Schools=== #RWTH Aachen University. Every two year Aachen University hosts International Glass Fibers Symposium where basalt fiber is devoted a separate section. The university conducts regular research to study and improve basalt fiber properties. Textile concrete is also more corrosion-resistant and more malleable than conventional concrete. Replacement of carbon fibers with basalt fibers can significantly enhance the application fields of the innovative composite material that is textile concrete, says Andreas Koch. #the Institute for Lightweight Design at the TU BerlinL. Fahrmeir, R. Künstler, I. Pigeot, G. Tutz, Statistik – Der Weg zur Datenanalyse. 5. Auflage, Springer-Verlag, Berlin/Heidelberg, (2005). #the Institute for Lightweight Design Materials Science at the University of Hannover #the German Plastics Institute (DKI) in Darmstadt(the main work is the book “Konstruieren mit Faser-Kunststoff-Verbunden” of Helmut Schürmann) #The Technical University of Dresden had contributed in the studying of basalt fibers. Textile reinforcements in concrete construction - basic research and applications. The Peter Offermann covers the range from the beginning of fundamental research work at the TU Dresden in the early 90s to the present. The idea that textile lattice structures made of high-performance threads for constructional reinforcement could open up completely new possibilities in construction was the starting point for today's large research network. Textile reinforcements in concrete construction - basic research and applications. The Peter Offermann covers the range from the beginning of fundamental research work at the TU Dresden in the early 90s to the present. The idea that textile lattice structures made of high-performance threads for constructional reinforcement could open up completely new possibilities in construction was the starting point for today's large research network. As a novelty, parallel applications to the research with the required approvals in individual cases, such as the world's first textile reinforced concrete bridges and the upgrading of shell structures with the thinnest layers of textile concrete, are reported. #University of Applied Sciences Regensburg, Department of Mechanical Engineering. Mechanical characterization of basalt fibre reinforced plastic with different fabric reinforcements – Tensile tests and FE-calculations with representative volume elements (RVEs). Marco Romano, Ingo Ehrlich.B. Jungbauer, M. Romano, I. Ehrlich, Bachelorthesis, University of Applied Sciences Regensburg, Laboratory of Composite Technology, Regensburg, (2012). ==Uses== {{div col}} *Heat protection[http://www.albarrie.com/techfabricscontinuousfiber.aspx Albarrie - BASALT FIBER] *Friction materials *Windmill blades *Lamp posts *Ship hulls *Car bodies *Sports equipment *Speaker cones *Cavity wall ties *Rebar[http://www.greenocean.nl Green Ocean] *Load bearing profiles *CNG cylinders and pipes *Absorbent for oil spills *Chopped strand for concrete reinforcement *High pressure vessels (e.g. tanks and gas cylinders) *Pultruded rebar for concrete reinforcement (e.g. for bridges and buildings) {{div col end}} ==Design codes== ===Russia=== Since October 18, 2017, JV 297.1325800.2017 "Fibreconcrete constructions with nonmetallic fiber has been put into operation. Design rules, "which eliminated the legal vacuum in the design of basalt reinforced fiber reinforced concrete. According to paragraph 1.1. the standard extends to all types of non-metallic fibers (polymers, polypropylene, glass, basalt and carbon). When comparing different fibers, it can be noted that polymer fibers are inferior to mineral strengths, but their use makes it possible to improve the characteristics of building composites. ==See also== * [[Pele's hair]] * [[Mineral wool]] * [[Glass wool]] * [[Rock wool]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *E. Lauterborn, Dokumentation Ultraschalluntersuchung Eingangsprüfung, Internal Report wiweb Erding, Erding,bOctober (2011). *K. Moser, Faser-Kunststoff-Verbund – Entwurfs- und Berechnungsgrundlagen. VDI-Verlag, Düsseldorf, (1992). *N. K. Naik, Woven Fabric Composites. revision.text:
[[File:Batoning.jpg|thumb|Batoning a piece of wood]] '''Batoning''' is the technique of cutting or splitting wood by using a [[club (weapon)|baton]]-sized stick or [[mallet]] to repeatedly strike the spine of a sturdy [[knife]], [[chisel]] or [[blade]] in order to drive it through wood, similar to how a [[froe]] is used.<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tjs85I4_TWwC Field & Stream]'' Mar 2006, p.45</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4WiaMCK0kJcC&pg=PA110 Field & Stream]'' Dec 2008 - Jan 200, p.113</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mfc_M6bXNv8C&pg=PA175 98.6 Degrees: The Art of Keeping Your Ass Alive!]'', Cody Lundin, Russ Miller, p.175</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mPfo9ect6fsC Fundamentals of search and rescue]'', Donald C. Cooper, p.72</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=67735&cat=51&ap=2 |title=Batoning Chisel - Lee Valley Tools |publisher=Leevalley.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref> The batoning method can be used to make kindling or desired forms such as boards, slats or notches. The practice is most useful for obtaining dry wood from the inside of logs for the purpose of [[fire making]].
==Tools== Tools used in batoning are: a strong, fixed-blade, preferably full tang knife or [[machete]] with a thick spine, and a club-sized length of dense or [[green wood]] for striking the knife's spine and tip.
==Technique== The basic method involves repeatedly striking the spine of the knife to force the middle of the blade into the wood. The tip is then struck, to continue forcing the blade deeper, until a split is achieved.<ref>McCann, John D.. Stay Alive: Survival Skills You Need. Krause Publications (24 Oct 2011).</ref>
==Uses and advantages== This technique is useful for the simple splitting of wood for kindling, to access dry wood within a wet log, and for the production of shingles, slats, or boards. It is also useful for cutting notches, or making clean crosscuts against the grain of the wood.{{Citation needed|date=April 2014}} The technique is also especially useful when a chopping tool is not available.
==Hazards== Care must be taken to avoid damage to the knife. Breakage of the blade is a common result of striking the spine of the knife at an angle. If this happens the broken blade can become irretrievably embedded within the split. In a survival situation, this can be catastrophic.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://shilohtv.com/?p=6494 |title=Batoning: How to Safely Baton With Your Knife (With Video) |publisher=ShilohTV |date=2010-05-15 |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Bushcraft]] *[[Fire making]] *[[Scoutcraft]] *[[Survival skills]] *[[Woodcraft]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Batoning}} * {{dmoz|Recreation/Outdoors/Survival_and_Primitive_Technology/|Survival and Primitive Technology}}
[[Category:Firelighting materials]] [[Category:Primitive technology]] [[Category:Procedural knowledge]] [[Category:Scoutcraft]] [[Category:Simple living]] [[Category:Survival skills]] [[Category:Woodworking]]

'''Blue goo''' is a sticky, plasticky, blueish-grey, [[clay]]-textured soil derived from a highly weathered [[serpentinite]] [[mélange]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url =http://jsedres.geoscienceworld.org/content/46/4/913.abstract |title = Sedimentology of a Melange: Franciscan of Trinidad, California|last = Aalto|first = Ken R.|date = 1976|journal = Journal of Sedimentary Petrology|doi = 10.1306/212F7090-2B24-11D7-8648000102C1865D |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 46|issue = 4|pages = 913–929}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www2.humboldt.edu/geology/courses/geology109/akl_109_labs/2009_labs/109_lab_6_trinidad_ft.pdf|title = Trinidad Lab Manual|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Department of Geology. Humboldt State University.|first = }}</ref> The name derives from the soil's color; a result of undergoing [[Hypoxia (environmental)|anaerobic]] conditions and becoming gleyed.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = The Nature and Properties of Soils|last = Brady|first = Nyle C.|publisher = Pearson-Prentice Hall|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Upper Saddle River, NJ|pages = 990|last2 = Weil|first2 = Ray R.|edition = 14}}</ref> A greyer variation is called "grey goo".<ref name=":1" /> Blue goo is primarily found along the Northern California coast.<ref name=":1" />
== Parent material == The [[Franciscan Assemblage|Franciscan Complex]] is the [[bedrock]] from which blue goo is derived.<ref name=":0" /> It stretches along the coastline from [[Central Coast (California)|Central California]] up to Southern [[Oregon]] and contains sheared materials from both the [[Pacific Plate|Pacific]] and [[North American Plate]]s that have accumulated in the [[accretionary wedge]].<ref name=":0" />
The rock types that produce blue goo include: [[Greenschist|greenstones]], [[chert]]s, [[basalt]]s, [[shale]]s, [[sandstone]]s, [[schist]]s, and serpenitites.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Geology of Eel River Valley area, Humboldt County, California : Ogle, Burdette Adrian : Free Download & Streaming|url = https://archive.org/details/geologyofeelrive00oglerich|website = Internet Archive|accessdate = December 17, 2015}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Franciscan Geology at Patrick’s Point, California|last = Tula|first = Alex|date = 1972|journal = Senior Thesis. Department of Geology. Humboldt State University.|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Earthflow Movement Characteristics at Truttman Sink: A Franciscan Complex Mélange Coastal Headland|last = Gustason|first = Edmund R.|date = 1979|journal = Senior Thesis. Department of Geology. Humboldt State University.|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> These materials mixed together forming a "plum pudding" or a mélange.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> This mélange decomposed through [[weathering]] to form blue goo.<ref>{{Cite book |url =http://www2.humboldt.edu/natmus/get-outside/fossils/Geol-Fossil-Guide.pdf |title = Unearthing Evidence of Creatures from Deep Time: A Beginner's Fossil Guide to the Northern California Coast |last = Anderson |first = Leslie S. |date = 2011 |page=6 |publisher = Humboldt State University |doi = |pmid = |access-date = January 17, 2016 }}</ref>
== Common features == Clay soils like blue goo have the highest water-holding capacity when compared with other soils, giving them a low draining capacity.<ref name=":2" /> This kind of habitat is unsuitable for most plants,<ref name=":2" /> but the [[North Coast (California)|Northern California coastline]] maintains high levels of vegetation year round.
Due to blue goo's clayey texture, it slips when overly saturated.<ref name=":4" /> This slippage is increased in heavy rainfall areas and in shallow soils; deep soils have more total [[Porosity|pore space]] and are not as prone to slippage.<ref name=":2" /> These features contribute to the landslide-ridden environments found along the Northern Californian coast.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
== Locations == The Franciscan Complex, from which blue goo is derived, extends from Central California up the coast through parts of Southern Oregon.<ref name=":0" /> But blue goo has only been found in two Northern Californian regions located in [[Humboldt County, California|Humboldt County]]: the [[Trinidad, California|Trinidad]] region and the [[Orick, California|Orick]] region. Blue goo is thought to also be found in the [[Eel River (California)|Eel River]] region and along the Southern Oregon coastline.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Clay]] [[Category:Geology of California]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Toy |name = Chatter Telephone |image = Chatter Phone Toy.jpg |caption=Fisher-Price Chatter Phone toy from a [[Museum of Hartlepool]] collection of objects which represent everyday life in the area (1950s through present) |type = Toy [[telephone]] |inventor = |country = [[United States]] |company = [[Fisher-Price]] |from = {{Start date and age|1962||}} |to = present |materials = Wood, plastic |website = |slogan = }}
The '''Chatter Telephone''' is a pull toy for toddlers 12 to 36 months of age.<ref name="FP1">{{cite news|url=http://www.fisher-price.com/en_US/brands/babytoys/products/5663|title=Brilliant Basics™ Chatter Telephone®|work=Fisher-Price|accessdate=8 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603020849/http://www.fisher-price.com/en_US/brands/babytoys/products/5663#|archive-date=2013-06-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Introduced in 1962 by the [[Fisher-Price]] company as the "Talk Back Phone" for infants and children, the Chatter Telephone is a roll along pull toy. It has a smiling face, and when the toy is pulled, it makes a chattering sound and the eyes move up and down. The toy has a [[rotary dial]] that rings a bell, and was conceived as a way to teach children how to dial a phone.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Coopee|first1=Todd|title=Chatter Phone from Fisher-Price (1962)|url=https://toytales.ca/chatter-phone-fisher-price-1962/|website=ToyTales.ca}}</ref>
The original version was made of wood, with a [[polyethylene]] receiver and cord.<ref name="TN1">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7RkfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5oEAAAAIBAJ&dq=fisher-price%20chatter%20telephone&pg=5061%2C966072|title=Louis Wiesel: Your Christmas Wond [sic] Fisher Price Toys|date=1963-12-05|work=The Tuscaloosa News|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> In 2000, Fisher-Price changed the [[rotary dial]] for a push-button version with lights in an effort to modernize the toy, but consumers complained and the rotary version returned to the market the following year.<ref name="NYT2">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/10/business/where-did-you-go-raggedy-ann-toys-in-the-age-of-electronics.html?pagewanted=3|title=Where Did You Go, Raggedy Ann?; Toys in the Age of Electronics|last=Barnes|first=Julian|date=2001-02-10|work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> The Chatter Telephone was designed by [[Ernest Thornell]],<ref>Shared in a phone conversation on 8-31-16 between Eric Smith and Mr. Thornell; he went on to share that the inspiration for the toy came from his daughter.</ref> whose daughter Tina would drag around a metal phone while playing. This gave him the idea of adding wheels, which with a bent axle permitted the movement of eyes, adding to the "whimsical" nature, that [[Herman Fisher]] desired of all Fisher-Price toys (from phone conversation with Ernie Thornell and recollections of Herm Fisher by John Smith).
From its introduction through the 1970s, the Chatter Telephone was Fisher-Price's best selling product.<ref name="MW1"> {{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=39ElAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XfMFAAAAIBAJ&dq=chatter-telephone&pg=3280%2C2693795 |title=Flash is fine but kids still go for classic toys |last=Moss |first=Meredith |date=1980-12-09 |work=The Miami News |publisher=The Cox News Service |accessdate=7 March 2010 }}</ref> It has been cited as one of the company's offerings that helped save Fisher Price in the 1990s following a failed attempt to market toys for older children in the late 1980s,<ref name="GS1"> {{ cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PUAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZuoDAAAAIBAJ&dq=chatter-telephone&pg=1666%2C8066537 | title=Kids Save the Day for Fisher Price | accessdate=2010-03-07 | last=Germain | first=David | publisher=AP | newspaper=Gainesville Sun | date=1992-12-25 }}</ref> and enjoys continuing popularity.<ref name="wctv">{{cite news|url=http://www.wctv.tv/news/headlines/36800434.html|title=Retro Toys|date=2008-12-28|publisher=WCTV Tallahassee Thomasville Valdosta|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> It is available both as an authentic reproduction<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.backtobasicstoys.com/item/productid/5761/txt/Fisher_Price_Chatter_Telephone_Toy |title=Fisher Price Chatter Telephone |publisher=www.backtobasicstoys.com |accessdate=7 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128113245/http://www.backtobasicstoys.com/item/productid/5761/txt/Fisher_Price_Chatter_Telephone_Toy |archivedate=28 November 2009 |df= }}</ref> and in a modern form.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fisher-price.com/fp.aspx?st=10&e=product&pid=5663|title=Chatter Phone-Fisher Price Toys|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref>
==Cultural references== In 1985, Fisher-Price offered to donate a Chatter Telephone, Rock A Stack, and Activity Center to [[NASA]] for Senator [[Jake Garn]] to play with while on the [[STS-51-D]] space shuttle mission. This offer was rejected as NASA felt there was insufficient time to test the toys for safety.<ref name="SR1">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Gw0SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C-8DAAAAIBAJ&dq=chatter-telephone&pg=6745%2C4345729|title=Space senator's toys must be borrowed|date=1985-02-24|work=The Spokesman Review|accessdate=7 March 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In 2003, the Chatter Telephone was listed as one of the 100 most memorable toys of the 20th century by the [[Toy Industry Association]].<ref name="AB1">{{cite news|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/manufacturing/miscellaneous-mfg-doll-toy-games-games/5673984-1.html|title=Toy Industry Association Announces Its "Century of Toys List"|date=2003-01-21 |work=All Business|publisher=Business Wire|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref>
In 2005, the Chatter Telephone was chosen as one of [[Dr. Toy]]'s Best Classic Toys.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drtoy.com/2005_1/winners.html|title=Dr. Toy's Best Classic Toys, 2005|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref>
Chatter Telephone appears in the 2010 animated film ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' as a minor character, helping [[Sheriff Woody|Woody]] save his friends from Lotso. He is voiced by [[Teddy Newton]] and speaks with a [[film noir]] style, and a brooklyn accent.<ref>{{IMDb title|id=0435761|title=Toy Story 3}}</ref>
Chatter Telephone appears in the 2017 animated film "[[The Boss Baby]]".
In the 1999 movie, [[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]], [[Elmo (Sesame Street)|Elmo]] owns a chatter telephone.
The Powerpuff [[hotline]], a telephone from ''[[The Powerpuff Girls]]'', somewhat bears a few resemblances to a Chatter Telephone.
In ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode, "[[Moe Baby Blues]]", the Chatter Telephone appears in [[Maggie Simpson|Maggie]]'s room.
The Chatter Telephone influenced a real-life art car created by Howard Davis for his telecommunications company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thephonecar.com/ |title=The Phone Car |accessdate=10 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429005623/http://www.thephonecar.com/ |archivedate=29 April 2011 |df= }}</ref>
A Chatter Telephone appears on the cover of American [[Rock music|rock]] band [[Thee Oh Sees]]' 2011 album [[Castlemania]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.fisher-price.com/fp.aspx?st=10&e=product&pid=5663 The official site of Fisher-Price for Chatter Telephone]
{{Fisher-Price Brands}}

revision.comment: /* Observation process */Follow-up, WL 1 first-publisher; [[WP:GenFixes]] on; using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:Transit of Mercury, 2006-11-08 2.jpg|thumb|[[Transit of mercury]] chord across the [[sun]]]] In the field of [[astronomy]] the term '''chord''' typically refers to a line crossing an object which is formed during an [[occultation]] event. By taking accurate measurements of the start and end times of the event, in conjunction with the known location of the observer and the object's [[orbit]], the length of the chord can be determined giving an indication of the size of the occulting object. By combining observations made from several different locations, multiple chords crossing the occulting object can be determined giving a more accurate shape and size model. This technique of using multiple observers during the same event has been used to derive more sophisticated shape models for [[asteroid]]s, whose shape can be highly irregular. A notable example of this occurred in 2002 when the asteroid [[345 Tercidina]] underwent a stellar occultation of a very bright star as seen from [[Europe]]. During this event a team of at least 105 observers recorded 75 chords across the asteroid's surface allowing for a very accurate size and shape determination.<ref name=euraster>{{cite web | date = 2002-09-17 | title = 2002 European Asteroidal Occultation Results | publisher = euraster.net (a website for Asteroidal Occultation Observers in Europe) | url = http://www.euraster.net/results/2002/index.html#0917-345 | accessdate = 2008-12-03}} [http://www.euraster.net/results/2002/20020917-Tercidina-cbf2.gif (Chords)]</ref>
In addition to using a known orbit to determine an objects size, the reverse process can also be used. In this usage the occulting object's size is taken to be known and the occultation time can be used to determine the length of the chord the background object traced across the foreground object. Knowing this chord and the foreground object's size, a more precise orbit for the object can be determined.
This usage of the term "chord" is similar to the geometric concept (see: [[Chord (geometry)]]). The difference being that in the geometric sense a chord refers to a line segment whose ends lie on a circle, whereas in the astronomical sense the occulting shape is not necessarily circular.
==Observation process==
Because an occultation event for an individual object is quite rare, the process of observing occultation events begins with the creation of a list of candidate targets. The list is generated from a computer by analyzing the orbital motions of a large collection of objects with known orbital parameters. Once a candidate event has been chosen whose [[ground track]] passes over the site of an observer, the preparations for the observation begin. A few minutes before the event is expected to happen the observing telescope is targeted to the target [[star]] and the star's [[lightcurve]] is recorded. The recording of the lightcurve continues during and for a short time after the predicted event. This extra recording time is due in part to uncertainties in the occulting objects orbit but also due to the possibility of detecting other objects orbiting the primary object (for example in the case of a [[binary asteroid]], also the [[Planetary ring|ring]] system around the planet [[Uranus]] was detected this way<ref name="Elliot-1977">{{cite journal | title = The rings of Uranus | last = Elliot | first = J. L. | last2 = Dunham | first2 = E. | last3 = Mink | first3 = D. | publisher = [[Cornell University]] | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v267/n5609/abs/267328a0.html |date = 1977 | accessdate=2010-07-11 | volume=267 | issue=5609 | doi=10.1038/267328a0|bibcode = 1977Natur.267..328E }}</ref>).
The exact method of lightcurve determination is dependent on the specific equipment available to the observer and the goals of the observation, however in all occultation events accurate timing is an essential component of the observation process. The exact time that the foreground object eclipses the other can be used to work out a very precise position along the occulting object's orbit. Also, since the duration of the drop in the measured lightcurve gives the object's size and since occultation events typically only last somewhere on the order of a few seconds, very fast [[Shutter speed|integration times]] are required to allow for high [[temporal resolution]] along the lightcurve. A second method of achieving very high temporal accuracy is to actually use a long exposure and allow the target star to drift across the CCD during the exposure. This method, known as the trailed image method, produces a streak along the photograph whose thickness corresponds to the brightness of the target star with the distance along the streak direction indicates time; this allows for very high temporal accuracy even when the target star may be too dim for the method described above using high frequency short exposures.<ref name="Kravtsov-2007">{{Cite journal | title = Observations of Asteroid Occultations by the Trailed-Image Method | first = F. I. | last = Kravtsov |author2=Lukyanik, I. V. | journal = Kinematics and Physics of Celestial Bodies | date = 2008 | volume = 24 | issue = 6 | pages = 317–322 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/4u5j048k85422063/ | doi = 10.3103/S0884591308060081|bibcode = 2008KPCB...24..317K }}</ref> With high enough temporal resolution even the angular size of the background star can be determined.<ref name="Kravtsov-2007"/>
Once the lightcurve has been recorded the chord across the occulting object can be determined via calculation. By using the start and end times of the occultation event the position in space of both the observer and the occulting object can be worked out (a process complicated by the fact that both the object and the observer are moving). Knowing these two locations, combined with the direction to the background object, the two endpoints of the chord can be determined using simple [[geometry]].
==External links== * [http://asteroidoccultation.com/ Upcoming Asteroid Occultation Events] * [http://lunar-occultations.com/iota/iotandx.htm The International Occultation Timing Association] * [http://www.occultations.net/occultations-asteroids.htm A Brief Discussion of Occultations by Asteroids]
==References==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Astronomical events]]

revision.comment: /* Gas Sensor */
revision.text:
In [[materials research|materials]] and [[electric battery]] research, '''cobalt oxide nanoparticles''' usually refers to particles of [[cobalt(II,III) oxide]] {{chem|Co|3|O|4}} of nanometer size, with various shapes and crystal structures.
Cobalt oxide nanoparticles have potential applications in [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion batteries]]<ref name=DuN/><ref name=WuZS/> and electronic [[gas sensor]]s.<ref name=ParkJS/><ref name=LiW/>
==Applications== ===Lithium-ion Battery=== The [[anode]]s of [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion batteries]] are often made of oxides of [[cobalt]], [[nickel]], or [[iron]], that can readily and reversibly incorporate lithium ions in their molecular structure. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles, such as [[inorganic nanotube|nanotubes]],<ref name=DuN>{{cite journal|last1=Du|first1=N.|last2=Zhang|first2=H.|last3=Chen|first3=B. D.|last4=Wu|first4=J. B.|last5=Ma|first5=X. Y.|last6=Liu|first6=Z. H.|last7=Zhang|first7=Y. Q.|last8=Yang|first8=D. R.|last9=Huang|first9=X. H.|last10=Tu|first10=J. P.|title=Porous Co3O4 Nanotubes Derived From Co4(CO)12 Clusters on Carbon Nanotube Templates: A Highly Efficient Material For Li-Battery Applications|journal=Advanced Materials|date=17 December 2007|volume=19|issue=24|pages=4505–4509|doi=10.1002/adma.200602513}}</ref> offer high surface-to-volume ratio and short path length for [[lithium]] cation transport, leading to high reversible capacity and good cycle life. The particles may incorporate other substances, asfor example [[diphenylalanine]]/cobalt oxide hybrid nanowires.<ref name=RyuJK>{{cite journal|last1=Ryu|first1=Jungki|last2=Kim|first2=Sung-Wook|last3=Kang|first3=Kisuk|last4=Park|first4=Chan Beum|title=Synthesis of Diphenylalanine/Cobalt Oxide Hybrid Nanowires and Their Application to Energy Storage|journal=ACS Nano|date=26 January 2010|volume=4|issue=1|pages=159–164|doi=10.1021/nn901156w}}</ref>
[[File:Cobale oxide graphene composite white background.tif|thumb|Cobalt oxide (Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) nanoparticles anchored on a single sheet of graphene.]] Cobalt oxide particles may be anchored on substrates such as [[graphene]] to improve the dimensional stability of the anode and to prevent particle aggregation during lithium charge and discharge processes.<ref name=WuZS>{{cite journal|last1=Wu|first1=Zhong-Shuai|last2=Ren|first2=Wencai|last3=Wen|first3=Lei|last4=Gao|first4=Libo|last5=Zhao|first5=Jinping|last6=Chen|first6=Zongping|last7=Zhou|first7=Guangmin|last8=Li|first8=Feng|last9=Cheng|first9=Hui-Ming|title=Graphene Anchored with CoO Nanoparticles as Anode of Lithium Ion Batteries with Enhanced Reversible Capacity and Cyclic Performance|journal=ACS Nano|date=22 June 2010|volume=4|issue=6|pages=3187–3194|doi=10.1021/nn100740x}}</ref>
===Gas Sensor=== Hollow nanospheres of cobalt oxide have been investigated as materials for [[gas sensor]] electrodes, for the detection of toluene, acetone, and other organic vapors.<ref name=ParkJS>{{cite journal|last1=Park|first1=Jinsoo|last2=Shen|first2=Xiaoping|last3=Wang|first3=Guoxiu|title=Solvothermal synthesis and gas-sensing performance of Co3O4 hollow nanospheres|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|date=March 2009|volume=136|issue=2|pages=494–498|doi=10.1016/j.snb.2008.11.041}}</ref>
Cobalt oxide nanoparticles anchored on single-walled [[carbon nanotube]]s have been investigated for sensing [[nitrogen oxide]]s {{chem|NO|''x''}} and [[hydrogen]]. This application takes advantage of the reactivity between the gas and the oxide, as well as the electrical connection with the substrate (both being [[p-type semiconductor]]s). Nitrogen oxides react with the oxide as [[electron acceptor]]s, reducing the electrode's resitance; whereas hydrogen acts as an [[electron donor]], increasing the resistance.<ref name=LiW>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Wei|last2=Jung|first2=Hyuck|last3=Hoa|first3=Nguyen Duc|last4=Kim|first4=Dojin|last5=Hong|first5=Soon-Ku|last6=Kim|first6=Hyojin|title=Nanocomposite of cobalt oxide nanocrystals and single-walled carbon nanotubes for a gas sensor application|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|date=September 2010|volume=150|issue=1|pages=160–166|doi=10.1016/j.snb.2010.07.023}}</ref>
===Medicine=== Cobalt oxide nanoparticles have been observed to readily enter [[cell (biology)|cells]], a property that conceivably could lead to applications in hyperthermic treatment, gene therapy and drug delivery. However, their toxicity is an obstacle that would have to be overcome.<ref name=PapisE>{{cite journal|last1=Papis|first1=Elena|last2=Rossi|first2=Federica|last3=Raspanti|first3=Mario|last4=Dalle-Donne|first4=Isabella|last5=Colombo|first5=Graziano|last6=Milzani|first6=Aldo|last7=Bernardini|first7=Giovanni|last8=Gornati|first8=Rosalba|title=Engineered cobalt oxide nanoparticles readily enter cells|journal=Toxicology Letters|date=September 2009|volume=189|issue=3|pages=253–259|doi=10.1016/j.toxlet.2009.06.851}}</ref>
==Synthesis==
===Hydrothermal=== Cobalt oxide is often obtained by [[hydrothermal synthesis]] in an autoclave.<ref name=Witt>{{cite journal|last1=Whittingham|first1=M Stanley|title=Hydrothermal synthesis of transition metal oxides under mild conditions|journal=Current Opinion in Solid State and Materials Science|date=April 1996|volume=1|issue=2|pages=227–232|doi=10.1016/S1359-0286(96)80089-1}}</ref>
[[One-pot synthesis|One-pot]] hydrothermal synthesis of metal oxide hollow spheres starts with carbohydrates and metal salts dissolved in water at 100-200 °C. The reaction produces carbon spheres, with metal ions integrated into the hydrophobic shell. The carbon cores are removed by [[calcination]], leaving hollow metal oxide spheres. Surface area and thickness of the shell can be manipulated by varying the carbohydrate to metal salt concentration, as well as the temperature, pressure, and [[pH]] of the reaction medium, and the cations of the starting salts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Titirici|first1=Maria-Magdalena|last2=Antonietti|first2=Markus|last3=Thomas|first3=Arne|title=A Generalized Synthesis of Metal Oxide Hollow Spheres Using a Hydrothermal Approach|journal=Chemistry of Materials|date=August 2006|volume=18|issue=16|pages=3808–3812|doi=10.1021/cm052768u}}</ref> The completion time for the procedure varies from hours to days.<ref name=LuAH>{{cite journal|last1=Lu|first1=An-Hui|last2=Salabas|first2=E. L.|last3=Schüth|first3=Ferdi|title=Magnetic Nanoparticles: Synthesis, Protection, Functionalization, and Application|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|date=12 February 2007|volume=46|issue=8|pages=1222–1244|doi=10.1002/anie.200602866}}</ref> [[File:HydrothermalFinalSharp.png|thumb|center|upright=2.0|Hydrothermal Synthesis of Cobalt Oxide Hollow Sphere.]] A drawback of this approach is a smaller yield compared to other methods.
===Thermal decomposition=== [[File:Solventfree.png|thumb|upright=1.5|TEM image (right) of cobalt oxide nanoparticles produced by thermal decomposition of organometallic precursor Co-salen (left).]] Another route to the synthesis of cobalt oxide nanoparticles is the thremaldecomposition of organometallic compounds. For example, heating the [[metal salen complex]] [[bis(salicylaldehyde)ethylenediiminecobalt(II)]] ("Co-salen") in air to 500 °C.<ref name=SharmaJK>{{cite journal|last1=Sharma|first1=J.K.|last2=Srivastava|first2=Pratibha|last3=Singh|first3=Gurdip|last4=Akhtar|first4=M. Shaheer|last5=Ameen|first5=S.|title=Green synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles and their applications in thermal decomposition of ammonium perchlorate and dye-sensitized solar cells|journal=Materials Science and Engineering: B|date=March 2015|volume=193|pages=181–188|doi=10.1016/j.mseb.2014.12.012}}</ref> <ref name=Salav>{{cite journal|last1=Salavati-Niasari|first1=Masoud|last2=Khansari|first2=Afsaneh|title=Synthesis and characterization of Co3O4 nanoparticles by a simple method|journal=Comptes Rendus Chimie|date=April 2014|volume=17|issue=4|pages=352–358|doi=10.1016/j.crci.2013.01.023}}</ref> The precursor Co-salen can be obtained by reacting [[cobalt(II) acetate|cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate]] in [[propanol]] at 50 °C under nitrogen atmosphere with the [[salen ligand]] (bis(salicylaldehyde)ethylenediimine).<ref name=Salav/>
===From anchored precursors===
Cobalt oxide/graphene composite are synthesized by first forming [[cobalt(II) hydroxide]] {{chem|Co|(|OH|)|2}} on the graphene sheet from a cobalt(II) salt and [[ammonium hydroxide]] {{chem|NH|4|OH}}, which is then heated to 450 °C for two hours to yield the oxide.
==Safety==
Like most reactive cobalt compounds, cobalt oxide nanoparticles are toxic to humans and also aquatic life.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Cobalt compounds}} {{Oxides}}
[[Category:Nanoparticles by composition]] [[Category:Cobalt compounds]] [[Category:Oxides]] [[Category:Semiconductor materials]]
