revision.text:
[[File:Nissan LEAF (ZE0) front.JPG|thumb|{{As of|2016|08}}, the [[Nissan Leaf]] [[electric car]] is the all-time top selling [[plug-in electric vehicle]] in Japan with almost 69,000 units sold since 2010.<ref name=JapSales2015/><ref name=JapSales082016/>]]
{{As of|2016|12}}, the fleet of light-duty '''plug-in electric vehicles in Japan ''' ranked as the third largest in the world after China and the United States, with about 151,250 highway legal [[plug-in electric vehicle]]s sold in the country since 2009.<ref name=Outlook2017/><ref name=Global2mi/> The rate of growth of the Japanese plug-in segment slowed down from 2013, with annual sales falling behind Europe, the U.S. and China during 2014 and 2015.<ref name=TopSix2015/><ref name=Global700K/><ref name=Global2011_15/> The segment market share fell from 0.68% in 2014 to 0.59% in 2016.<ref name=Outlook2017/> The decline in plug-in car sales reflects the Japanese government and the major domestic carmakers decision to adopt and promote [[hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen]] [[fuel cell vehicle]]s instead of plug-in electric vehicles, although the first commercially produced hydrogen fuel cell automobiles began in 2015.<ref name=FCEV_BEV/><ref name=JapanFCEV/>
{{As of|2016|08}}, the [[Nissan Leaf]] all-electric car ranked as the all-time top selling plug-in electric vehicle in the country, with 68,819 units sold since December 2010.<ref name=JapSales2015/><ref name=JapSales082016/> Ranking second is the [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] with 34,830 units delivered through August 2016,<ref name=JapMiEV082016/> followed by the [[Toyota Prius PHV]] with 22,100 units sold through April 2016.<ref name=TMC9miHEVs/>
{{As of|2012|12}}, Japan was the country with the highest ratio of quick [[charging infrastructure|charging points]] to electric vehicles (EVSE/EV), with a ratio of 0.030 {{as of|2012|12|lc=y}}. The country's charging infrastructure included 1,381 public quick-charge stations and around 300 non-domestic slow charger points.<ref name=Outook2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/globalevoutlook_2013.pdf|title=Global EV Outlook 2013 - Understanding the Electric Vehicle Landscape to 2020|author=[[International Energy Agency]], Clean Energy Ministerial, and Electric Vehicles Initiative |publisher=International Energy Agency |date=April 2013|accessdate=2013-04-20}} ''See pp. 4, 6-8, and 11-12''.</ref> The Japanese government has set up a target to deploy 2 million slow chargers and 5,000 fast charging points by 2020.<ref name=Outook2013/>
==Introduction and sales== [[File:Top PEV global markets stock 2017 final with California.png|thumb |325px |Cumulative light-duty plug-in electric vehicle sales in Japan compared to the world's top-selling countries and regional markets {{as of|2017|12|lc=y}}. Japan ranks as the fourth largest plug-in country market.<ref name=Outlook2017/><ref name=Global2mi>{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/the-world-just-bought-its-two-millionth-plug-in-car/ |title=The World Just Bought Its Two-Millionth Plug-in Car | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com | date=2017-01-16 |accessdate=2017-01-17}} ''An estimated 2,032,000 highway-legal plug-in passenger cars and vans have been sold worldwide at the end of 2016. The top selling markets are China (645,708 new energy cars, including imports), Europe (638,000 plug-in cars and vans), and the United States (570,187 plug-in cars). The top European country markets are Norway (135,276), the Netherlands (113,636), France (108,065), and the UK (91,000). Total Chinese sales of domestically produced new energy vehicles, including buses and truck, totaled 951,447 vehicles. China was the top selling plug-in car market in 2016, and also has the world's largest stock of plug-in electric cars.''</ref><ref name=Sales2017US>{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2017-dashboard/ |title= December 2017 Dashboard | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates | date=2018-01-04 |accessdate=2018-01-23}} ''Plug-in electric car sales in the U.S. totaled 194,479 units in 2017, consisting of 104,487 all-electric cars and 89,992 plug-in hybrids. The plug-in car segment achieved a market share of 1.13% of new car sales.''</ref><ref name=OFV2017>{{cite web |url=http://www.ofvas.no/bilsalget-i-2017/category751.html |title=Bilsalget i 2017 | language=Norwegian |trans-title=Car sales in 2017 |author=Opplysningsrådet for Veitrafikken AS (OFV)|publisher=OFV|accessdate=2018-01-11}} ''A total of 71,737 plug-in electric vehicles were registered in Norway in 2017, consisting of: 33,025 new electric cars, 8,558 used imported all-electric cars, 29,236 new plug-in hybrid cars, 742 new all-electric vans, and 176 used imported all-electric vans.''</ref>]]
Cumulative light-duty plug-in electric vehicle sales in Japan totaled about 151,250 units between July 2009 and December 2016, consisting of 86,390 all-electric cars (57.1%) and 64,860 plug-in hybrids (42.9%).<ref name=Outlook2017>{{cite web |url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/GlobalEVOutlook2017.pdf |title=Global EV Outlook 2017: Two million and counting |author=[[International Energy Agency]] (IEA), Clean Energy Ministerial, and Electric Vehicles Initiative (EVI) |publisher=IEA Publications |date=June 2017 |accessdate=2018-01-20}} ''See pp. 5–7, 12–22, 27–28, and Statistical annex, pp. 49–51''.</ref> At the end of 2016, Japan ranked as the world's third largest light-duty plug-in vehicle country market after the China and the U.S.<ref name=Global2mi/> {{Asof|2016|09}}, total Japanese sales of light-duty plug-in vehicles represent 8.1% of the global stock of plug-ins.<ref name=ChinaUS092016>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/china-now-ties-us-for-leadership-in-cumulative-global-plug-in-sales/ | title=China Now Ties US For Leadership In Cumulative Global Plug-In Sales | first=Jeff | last=Cobb| work=HybridCars.com| date=2016-10-17| accessdate=2016-10-17}}</ref> The plug-in segment sales climbed from 1,080 units in 2009 to 12,630 in 2011, and reached 24,440 in 2012. Only [[all-electric car]]s were sold in the country between 2009 and 2011.<ref name=Outlook2016/> Global sales of pure electric cars in 2012 were led by Japan with a 28% [[market share]] of the segment sales. Japan ranked second after the U.S. in terms of its share of [[plug-in hybrid]] sales in 2012, with 12% of global sales.<ref name=Outook2013/>
About 30,600 highway-capable plug-in electric vehicles were sold in the country in 2013,<ref name=JapMiEV2011_14/><ref name=TMC7mi/><ref name=JapSales092014>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/nissan-leaf-sales-surge-almost-7000-month-september/|title=Nissan LEAF Sales Surge To Almost 7,000 In September|author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2014-10-26|accessdate=2014-10-26}} ''A total of 10,877 units were sold in Japan during the first nine months of 2014.''</ref> representing a 0.58% market share of the 5.3 million new automobiles and [[kei car]]s sold in 2013.<ref name=Japan2013/><ref name=Top6Global2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/top-6-plug-in-car-adopting-countries/|title=Top 6 Plug-In Vehicle Adopting Countries|author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com|date=2014-01-16|accessdate=2014-02-21}}</ref> In 2014 the segment sales remained flat with over 30,000 plug-in electric vehicles were sold, with the plug-in market share achieving a record market share of 1.06% of new car sales (kei cars not included).<ref name=Global700K>{{cite web| url=http://www.hybridcars.com/top-6-plug-in-vehicle-adopting-countries-2014/5/ | title=Top 6 Plug-In Vehicle Adopting Countries – 2014 |author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com| date=2015-02-18|accessdate=2016-06-25}}</ref> Accounting for kei cars, the plug-in segment market share falls to 0.7%.<ref name=Outlook2016/> During 2014, cumulative plug-in sales in the Japanese market passed the 100,000 unit mark. However, as a result of the slow growth from 2013, Japan was surpassed in 2014 by China, with over 50,000 units sold, as the second largest world market that year.<ref name=Global700K/> Sales totaled 24,660 units in 2015 and 24,851 units in 2016.<ref name=Outlook2017/> The segment market share declined from 0.68% in 2014 to 0.59% in 2016.<ref name=Outlook2017/> As a result of the slow down in sales that occurred after 2013, annual sales fell behind Europe, the U.S. and China during 2014 and 2015.<ref name=TopSix2015/><ref name=Global700K/><ref name=Global2011_15/>
[[File:Lawson-car.jpg|thumb|left|Mitsubishi i-MiEV recharging from an on-street [[charging station]] in Japan.]]
The first electric car available in the Japanese market was the [[Mitsubishi i MiEV]], launched for fleet customers in Japan in late July 2009.<ref name=AP100331>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=10256996|title=Japanese Start Buying Affordable Electric Cars|agency=Associated Press|work=ABC News|author=Yuri Kageyama|date=2010-04-01|accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/06/imiev-20090605.html|title=Mitsubishi Motors Begins Production of i-MiEV; Targeting 1,400 Units in Fiscal 2009|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2009-06-05|accessdate=2010-04-04}}</ref> Retail sales to the public began in April 2010.<ref name=Reuters100330>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTOE62T09V20100330 |title=Mitsubishi Motors lowers price of electric i-MiEV|date=2010-03-30 |author=Chang-Ran Kim |publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2010-04-25 }}</ref><ref name=Japan090606>{{cite news|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/business/view/mitsubishi-unveils-y459-mil-electric-car |title=Mitsubishi unveils Y4.59 mil electric car |date=2009-06-06 |publisher=Associated Press via Japan Today |accessdate=2010-04-24 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124417212155988023 |title=Mitsubishi Launches Electric Car |date=2009-06-08|author=John Murphy |publisher=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=2010-04-24 }}</ref> Cumulative sales since July 2009 reached 11,144 i-MiEVs through April 2016.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_042016/><ref name=MiEVJapan2009_13/> Sales of the [[Mitsubishi Minicab MiEV]] electric van began in December 2011, and a total of 6,172 units have been sold through April 2016.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_042016/><ref name=JapMiEV2013>{{cite web|url=http://evn.blog.eonet.jp/weblog/2014/01/i-miev201312-5b80.html|title=三菱 i-MiEVなどの2013年12月度 販売実績|language=Japanese|trans-title=Mitsubishi i-MiEV sales results for December 2013|publisher=Electric Vehicle News|date=2014-01-29|accessdate=2014-02-01}} ''Cumulative Outlander P-HEV sales in Japan totaled 9,608 units through December 2013.''</ref> A truck version of the Minicab MiEV was launched in January 2013,<ref name=MitsuPEVs>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/mitsubishis-pure-electric-vehicle-sales-tumbling-in-japan-as-outlander-phev-dominates/|title=Mitsubishi’s Pure Electric Vehicle Sales Tumbling in Japan as Outlander PHEV Dominates|author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-06-10|accessdate=2013-06-16}}</ref> with sales of 927 units through April 2016.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_042016/><ref name=JapMiEV2013/> Mitsubishi also launched in January 2013 a [[plug-in hybrid]] version of the Outlander, called the [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]], becoming the first [[SUV]] plug-in hybrid in the world's market.<ref name=JapPHEV>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/mitsubishi-outlander-phev-on-sale-in-japan-today-extended-promotional-video-released/|title=Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV On Sale In Japan Today, Extended Promotional Video Released|author=Jay Cole|publisher=Inside EVs|date=2013-01-24|accessdate=2013-01-28}}</ref> The SUV has an [[all-electric range]] of {{convert|60|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="JapPHEV"/> The Outlander P-HEV sold 9,608 units during 2013, ranking as the second top selling plug-in electric car in Japan after the Nissan Leaf.<ref name=JapMiEV2013/><ref name=Japan2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.ev-sales.blogspot.ca/2014/01/japan-december-2013.html|title=Japan December 2013|author=Jose Pontes|publisher=EV Sales|date=2014-01-30|accessdate=2014-02-21}} ''Excludes sales of [[Nissan NMC]] units (45), which is a low-speed neighborhood vehicle.''</ref> {{As of|2016|04}}, [[Mitsubishi Motors]] had sold 52,234 plug-in electric vehicles in Japan since July 2009.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_042016/><ref name=MiEVJapan2009_13/><ref name=JapMiEV2013/>
[[File:Mitsubishi Motors Minicab MiEV Van (Prototype) demo-car.jpg|thumb|[[Mitsubishi Minicab MiEV]] in Japan.]]
The first prototype battery switch station from [[Better Place (company)|Better Place]] was demonstrated in [[Yokohama]] on May 14, 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124223719358315997 |title=A High-Tech Twist on the Filling Station; In Japan, a California Start-Up Unveils System for Quickly Swapping Batteries in Electric Cars|author=[https://online.wsj.com/search/search_center.htmlKEYWORDS=JOHN+MURPHY&ARTICLESEARCHQUERY_PARSER=bylineAND John Murphy] |date=2009-05-09|accessdate=2009-10-05|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> On April 2010, a 90-day switchable-battery electric taxi demonstration project was launched in [[Tokyo]], using three [[Nissan Rogue]] crossover utility vehicles, converted into [[electric car]]s with switchable batteries provided by [[A123 Systems]]. The battery switch station deployed in Tokyo is more advanced than the Yokohama switch system demonstrated in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/04/bptaxi-20100426.html#more|title=Better Place Launches Switchable-Battery Electric Taxi Project in Tokyo; Converted Crossovers with A123 Systems Packs|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2010-04-26|accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/better-place-launches-tokyo-taxi-electric-car-test-2010-04-26 |title=Better Place launches electric-car test with Tokyo taxi firm |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=2010-04-26|accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.betterplace.com/2010/04/countdown-to-the-opening-of-the-world%E2%80%99s-first-switchable-battery-electric-taxi-operation/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120711072647/http://blog.betterplace.com/2010/04/countdown-to-the-opening-of-the-world%E2%80%99s-first-switchable-battery-electric-taxi-operation/ |archivedate=2012-07-11 |df= }}</ref> During the three-month field test the EV taxis accumulated over {{Convert|25,000|mi}} and swapped batteries 2,122 times, with an average battery swap time of 59.1 seconds. Nissan decided to continue the trial until late November 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2010/08/27/better-place-expands-tokyo-battery-swap-trials-taxis-have-chang/ |title=Tokyo battery swap trials|publisher=AutoblogGreen |author=Sam Abuelsamid|date=2010-08-27|accessdate=2010-10-28}}</ref>
Sales of the [[Nissan Leaf]] began on December 22, 2010, when the first 10 Leaf were delivered at the [[Kanagawa Prefecture]]. The Prefecture Government decided to assign six Leafs for official use and the other four were made available for the [[car rental]] service run by the local government.<ref name=JapanDeliver1>{{cite news|url=http://www.thegreencarwebsite.co.uk/blog/index.php/2010/12/22/nissan-delivers-first-leaf-in-japan/|title=Nissan delivers first Leaf in Japan|publisher=The Green Car Website|date=2010-12-22|accessdate=2010-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/94510/20101222/nissan-leaf-japan-kanagawa-prefectural-government.htm|title=Nissan delivers first LEAF cars in Japan|work=International Business Times|date=2010-12-22|accessdate=2010-12-23}}</ref> Sales of the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]] began in January 2012, and a total of 19,100 units have been sold through September 2014.<ref name=TMC7mi/> The [[Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid]] was introduced in Japan in June 2013 and it is available only for leasing, primarily to corporations and government agencies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/06/honda-20130621.html|title=Honda introduces Accord hybrid and plug-in in Japan; hybrid in US in October|author=Honda News|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-06-21|accessdate=2014-02-22}}</ref> {{As of|2013|12}}, the Accord PHEV ranked as the third best selling plug-in hybrid in the Japanese market.<ref name=JapAccord>{{cite news|url=http://asia.nikkei.com/print/article/16829|title=Plug-in hybrids quickly becoming Japan's favorite way to drive green |author=Naoki Watanabe|work=[[Nihon Keizai Shimbun|Nikkei Asian Review]]|date=2014-02-12|accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
[[File:Tesla Model S in Kobe, Japan (15869504139).jpg|thumb|left|Deliveries of the [[Tesla Model S]] in Japan began in September 2014.<ref name=ModelSjap/>]]
Sales of the plug-in electric drive segment during 2013 were led by the Nissan Leaf with 13,021 units sold, up from 11,115 in 2012, allowing the Leaf to continue as the top selling plug-in electric car in the country since 2011.<ref name=JapLeaf2013/> Also during 2013, a total of 45 [[Nissan NMC]] all-electric [[Neighborhood electric vehicle|low-speed neighborhood vehicle]]s were sold in the country.<ref name=Japan2013/> Sales during the first nine months of 2014 again were led by the Nissan Leaf with 10,877 units,<ref name=JapSales092014/> followed by the Outlander P-HEV with 8,630 units,<ref name=JapMiEV2011_14>{{cite web|url=http://evn.blog.eonet.jp/weblog/2014/10/mitsubishi-moto-2c47.html|title=三菱 i-MiEVなどの2014年9月度 生産・販売実績|language=Japanese|trans-title=Mitsubishi i-MiEV production and sales results for September 2014|publisher=Electric Vehicle News|date=2014-10-27|accessdate=2014-10-27}} ''A total of 5,334 Minicab vans and 669 mini truck versions have been sold through September 2014''.</ref> together representing 78.8% of the plug-in segment sales during this period.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_14/><ref name=TMC7mi/><ref name=JapSales092014/><ref name=JapLeaf2013/>
[[File:Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV 0328.JPG|thumb|The [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] was the top selling plug-in electric car in Japan in 2015.<ref name=Japan2015/>]]
Retail deliveries of the [[Tesla Model S]] began in Japan in September 2014.<ref name=ModelSjap>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2014/09/08/teslas-musk-in-tokyo-says-heart-of-model-s-is-japanese/|title=Tesla’s Musk, in Tokyo, Says ‘Heart’ of Model S Is Japanese|author=Takashi Mochizuki|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=2014-09-08|accessdate=2014-09-08}}</ref> The Leaf continued as the market leader in 2014 for the fourth year running with 14,177 units sold, followed by the Outlander P-HEV with 10,064 units, together representing about 80% of the plug-in segment sales in Japan in 2014.<ref name=JapMiEV2014>{{cite web|url=http://evn.blog.eonet.jp/weblog/2015/01/mitsubishi-moto-2c47.html|title=三菱 i-MiEVなどの2014年12月度 生産・販売実績 |language=Japanese|trans-title=Mitsubishi i-MiEV production and sales results for December 2014|publisher=Electric Vehicle News|date=2015-01-28|accessdate=2015-02-18}}.</ref><ref name=Jap122014>{{cite web|url=http://www.ev-sales.blogspot.ca/2015/01/japan-december-2014.html|title=Japan December 2014 |author=Jose Pontes|publisher=EVSales.com|date=2015-01-30|accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref><ref name=JapSales2014/>
In 2015 the Outlander plug-in hybrid surpassed the Leaf as the top selling plug-in electric car in the country that year with 10,996 units sold, while the Leaf sold 9,057 units.<ref name=Japan2015>{{cite web| url=http://ev-sales.blogspot.com.br/2016/02/japan-december-2015.html |title=Japan December 2015 |last=Jose |first=Pontes|publisher=EVSales.com|date=2016-02-08|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref> Japan is the Outlander P-HEV largest country market with 30,668 units sold through December 2015.<ref name=JapMiEV2011_15>{{cite web| url=http://evn.blog.eonet.jp/weblog/2016/01/mitsubishi-moto-2c47-2.html |title=三菱 i-MiEVなどの2015年12月度 販売実績 | language=Japanese |trans-title=Mitsubishi i-MiEV production and sales results for December 2015| work=Electric Vehicle News| date=2016-01-28| accessdate=2016-02-23}} ''A total of 30,668 Outlander P-HEVs have been sold in Japan through December 2015.''</ref> Nevertheless, at the end of 2015 the Nissan Leaf continued to rank as the all-time best-selling plug-in car in the country with 57,699 units sold.<ref name=JapSales2015/> {{As of|2015|12}}, cumulative sales of plug-in electric cars totaled 126,420 units since 2009.<ref name=Outlook2016>{{cite web| url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Global_EV_Outlook_2016.pdf | title=Global EV Outlook 2016: Beyond one million electric cars | author=[[International Energy Agency]] (IEA), Clean Energy Ministerial, and Electric Vehicles Initiative (EVI) | publisher=IEA Publications | date=May 2016 | accessdate=2016-10-01}} ''See pp. 4-5, and 24-25 and Statistical annex, pp. 34-37''.</ref>
During the first eight months of 2016 the Nissan Leaf led sales with 11,120 units delivered.<ref name=JapSales082016/> Since December 2010, Nissan has sold 68,819 units through August 2016, making the Leaf the all-time best-selling plug-in car in the country.<ref name=JapSales2015/><ref name=JapSales082016>{{cite web | url=http://insideevs.com/nissan-leaf-sales-in-japan-stay-strong-in-august/ | title=Nissan LEAF Sales In Japan Stay Strong In August | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| accessdate=2016-09-26 | date=2016-09-26}} ''A total of 11,120 Leafs were sold in Japan during the first eight months of 2016.''</ref> Between January and August 2016, a total of 4,162 Outlander P-HEVs were sold in Japan.<ref name=JapMiEV082016/> Sales of the Outlander plug-in hybrid fell sharply from April 2016 as a result of [[Mitsubishi Motors#Fuel mileage scandal|Mitsubishi's fuel mileage scandal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/mitsubishi-outlander-phev-sales-in-japan-down-nearly-90-in-july/ |title=Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV Sales In Japan Down Nearly 90% In July | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=2016-09-19| accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref> Since its inception, sales of the plug-in hybrid totaled 34,830 units through August 2016.<ref name=JapMiEV082016>{{cite web| url=http://evn.blog.eonet.jp/weblog/2016/09/mitsubishi-moto-2c47-1.html |title=三菱 アイミーブなどの2016年８月度 販売実績 | language=Japanese |trans-title=Mitsubishi i-MiEV production and sales results for August 2016| work=Electric Vehicle News| date=2016-09-28| accessdate=2016-10-01}} ''A total of 34,830 Outlander P-HEVs have been sold in Japan through August 2016.''</ref>

|- align=center |align=left|[[BMW i3]]<ref name=BMWi3Jap>{{cite news|url=http://business.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/eng/20140916/271299/|title=Big Subsidies for Foreign Electric Cars in Japan|author=Hiromi Sato|work=Nikkei Business|date=2014-09-16|accessdate=2014-10-28}}</ref>||2014||+ 400|| NA || NA || + 400<sup>(2)</sup> || colspan="5" bgcolor="#f0f0ff"|
|-align=center |bgcolor="#f0f0ff" colspan="2" |'''Total sales shown models Jul 2009 - Apr 2016'''|| bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 139,712 ||bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 10,982 ||bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 22,694 ||bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 31,891 || bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 30,587|| bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 26,867|| bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 13,347|| bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 2,359|| bgcolor="#f0f0ff"| 986 |- |colspan="11" style="background:#abcdef;"|<small>'''Notes:''' (1) The [[Tesla Model S]], Smart ED and [[Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid]] are also available in Japan, but sales figures are not available.<ref name=JapAccord/><br>(2) Sales only between April and August 2014.</small> |}
===Future trends=== [[File:Mirai trimmed.jpg|thumb|[[Toyota Mirai]] [[hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen]] [[fuel cell car]]]]
The rate of growth of the Japanese plug-in segment slowed down from 2013, with annual sales falling behind Europe, the U.S. and China during 2014 and 2015.<ref name=TopSix2015>{{cite news| url=http://www.hybridcars.com/top-six-plug-in-vehicle-adopting-countries-2015/ | title=Top Six Plug-in Vehicle Adopting Countries – 2015 |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2016-01-18|accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref><ref name=Global2011_15>{{cite web| url=http://insideevs.com/plug-in-electric-car-sales-visualized-from-2011-to-2015/ | title=Plug-In Electric Car Sales Visualized From 2011 to 2015 | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=2016-04-02| accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref> This trend reflects the Japanese government and the major domestic carmakers decision to adopt and promote [[hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen]] [[fuel cell vehicle]]s instead of plug-in electric vehicles.<ref name=FCEV_BEV>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autoshow-japan-electric-insight-idUSKCN0SM04F20151028 | title=Auto power play: Japan's hydrogen car vs China's battery drive | first1= Norihiko |last1=Shirouzu | first2=Paul | last2=Lienert | work=[[Reuters]] | date=2015-10-28 | accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref><ref name=JapanFCEV>{{cite web| url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/japans-big-bet-on-hydrogen | title=Japan Makes a Big Bet on the Hydrogen Economy | first=Jason | last=Deign |publisher=Green Tech Media | date=2015-02-10 | accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref> The Japanese strategy aims to focus in investing heavily in fuel-cell technology and infrastructure as part of a national policy to foster what it calls a [[hydrogen economy|hydrogen society]], where the zero-emission fuel would power homes and vehicles.<ref name=FCEV_BEV/>
In August 2012, Toyota announced its plans to start retail sales of a hydrogen fuel-cell [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]] in California in 2015. Toyota expects to become a leader in this technology.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/driveon/post/2012/08/toyota-to-start-selling-hydrogen-fuel-cell-car-in-2015/1#.UXK8KLWG18E|title=Toyota to start selling hydrogen fuel-cell car in 2015 |author=Alisa Priddle |work=[[USA Today]]|date=2013-03-17|accessdate=2012-08-08}}</ref> In addition, in September 2012 Toyota announced that is backing away from fully electric vehicles. The company's vice chairman, [[Takeshi Uchiyamada]], said "''The current capabilities of electric vehicles do not meet society’s needs, whether it may be the distance the cars can run, or the costs, or how it takes a long time to charge''." Toyota's emphasis would be re-focused on the hybrid concept, and 21 new hybrid gas-electric models scheduled to be on the market by 2015.<ref name=WP0912>{{cite news|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/Automotive/2012/09/24/Toyota-beefs-up-green-vehicles-plans-electric-car-for-this-year-fuel-cell-vehicle-by-2015.html|title=Toyota beefs up green vehicles, plans electric car for this year, fuel cell vehicle by 2015 |author=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Toledo Blade]] |date=2012-09-24|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ludwig, Sean|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/09/24/toyota-kills-electric-car-plans/|title=Toyota kills electric car plans, says 'capabilities of electric vehicles do not meet society’s needs'|publisher=[[VentureBeat]]|date=2012-09-24|accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
As part of [[Toyota]]'s effort to maintain its alternative propulsion lead, it launched for retail customers the [[Toyota Mirai]] [[hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen]] [[fuel cell vehicle]] in late 2014, and [[Honda]] plans to launch the [[Honda Clarity Fuel Cell|Clarity Fuel Cell]] by late 2016.<ref name=FCEV_BEV/> Toyota is responding to interest in the hydrogen economy in its home market, where, {{as of|2014|12|lc=y}}, there were 100,000 residential [[hydrogen]] [[fuel cell]]s already installed across Japan. The country is aiming for 5.3 million households, or roughly 10%, to have fuel cells by 2030.<ref name=JapanFCEV/> Nevertheless, in June 2015 Toyota announced its plans to continue a strong promotion of [[plug-in hybrid]]s starting with the introduction of the [[Prius Prime]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/business/view/toyota-gets-bullish-on-plug-in-hybrids-with-new-prius-prime | title=Toyota gets bullish on plug-in hybrids with new Prius Prime | first=Yuri | last=Kageyama | work=[[Japan Today]] | date=2016-06-17 | accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref>
In September 2016, Shoichi Kaneko, assistant chief engineer for the [[Prius Prime]], said in an interview with the website AutoblogGreen that creating the next-generation Prius will be a tremendously difficult challenge due to the physical limitations to improve the Prius' fuel economy. And considering that Toyota "wants to lead the way in reducing (and eventually eliminating) fossil fuels from its vehicles, simply making a better standard hybrid powertrain might not be enough," the carmaker is considering making every future Prius a [[plug-in hybrid]] beginning with the fifth-generation models.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/09/28/toyota-every-future-prius-plug-in-hybrid/ | title=Toyota: Every future Prius might be a plug-in hybrid | first=Sebastian | last=Blanco | work=Autoblog.com | date=2016-09-28 | accessdate=2016-10-02}}</ref>
==Charging infrastructure== The Japanese electric vehicle charging infrastructure climbed from only 60 public [[charging station]]s in early 2010<ref name="AP100331"/> to 1,381 public quick-charge stations {{as of|2012|12|lc=y}}, representing the largest deployment of fast chargers in the world. The number of non-domestic slow charger points increased to around 300 units.<ref name=Outook2013/> Japan also is the country with the highest ratio of quick charging points to electric vehicles (EVSE/EV), with a ratio of 0.030 {{as of|2012|12|lc=y}}.<ref name=Outook2013/> There are 1,967 [[CHAdeMO]] quick charging stations across the country by April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/sweden-uk-driving-growth-chademo-chargers-europe-1117/|title=Sweden and UK Drive Growth Of CHAdeMO Chargers In Europe To 1,117|author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-04-22|accessdate=2014-04-28}}</ref> The Japanese government has set up a target to deploy 2 million slow chargers and 5,000 fast charging points by 2020.<ref name=Outook2013/> Currently all Family Mart convenience stores with sufficient parking space have one space specialized for quick-charge use or are in the process of having one installed.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
==Government incentives== {{See also|Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Japan|l1=Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles in Japan}} {{update|section|date=February 2014}} The Japanese government introduced the first electric vehicle incentive program in 1996, and it was integrated in 1998 with the Clean Energy Vehicles Introduction Project, which provided subsidies and tax discounts for the purchase of [[electric vehicle|electric]], [[natural gas vehicle|natural gas]], [[methanol fuel|methanol]] and [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s. The project provided a purchase subsidy of up to 50% the incremental costs of a clean energy vehicle as compared with the price of a conventional engine vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evaap.org/pdf/incentive.pdf|title=Incentives for EV & HEV|date=October 2003|publisher=Electric Vehicle Association of Asia Pacific|accessdate=2010-06-06}}</ref> This program was extended until 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Max Ahman|title=Government policy and the development of electric vehicles in Japan|journal=Energy Policy|date=March 2006|pages=433–443|issue=34|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2004.06.011}}</ref>
[[File:Toyota PRIUS PHV G (ZVW35) front.JPG|thumb|[[Toyota Prius PHV]] (first generation)]]
In May 2009 the Japanese Diet passed the "Green Vehicle Purchasing Promotion Measure" that went into effect on June 19, 2009, but retroactive to April 10, 2009.<ref name=JAMAFact/> The program established tax deductions and exemptions for [[Green vehicle|environmentally friendly]] and fuel efficient vehicles, according to a set of stipulated environmental performance criteria, and the requirements are applied equally to both foreign and domestically produced vehicles. The program provided purchasing subsidies for two type of cases, consumers purchasing a new passenger car without trade-in (non-replacement program), and for those consumers buying a new car trading an used car registered 13 years ago or earlier ([[scrappage program]]).<ref name=JAMAFact>{{cite web|url=http://jama.org/pdf/FactSheet10-2009-09-24.pdf|title=Fact Sheet- Japanese Government Incentives for the Purchase of Environmentally Friendly Vehicles|publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|accessdate=2010-12-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226222150/http://www.jama.org/pdf/FactSheet10-2009-09-24.pdf|archivedate=2010-12-26|df=}}</ref><ref name=JAMA2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.jama-english.jp/publications/MIJ2010.pdf|title=The Motor Industry of Japan 2010|publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|accessdate=2010-12-24}} ''See pages 45–46''.</ref>
Subsidies for purchases of new environmentally friendly vehicles without scrapping a used car are 100,000 yen (~US$1,100) for the purchase of a standard or small car, and 50,000 yen (~US$550) for the purchase of a [[kei car|mini or kei vehicle]]. Subsidies for purchasing trucks and buses meeting the stipulated fuel efficiency and emission criteria vary between 200,000 yen (~US$2,100) to 900,000 yen (~US$9,600).<ref name=JAMAFact/><ref name=JAMANews>{{cite journal|url=http://www.jama-english.jp/asia/news/2009/vol36/index.html|publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|accessdate=2010-06-06|journal=News from JAMA Asia|issue=36|date=September 2009|title=Japan's measures to withstand impact of global crisis on its automotive industry - JAMA shares at the 4th Indonesia International Automotive Conference}}</ref><ref name=Outlook/>
Subsidies for purchases of new environmentally friendly vehicles in the case of owners scrapping a 13-year or older vehicle are 250,000 yen (~US$2,700) for the purchase of a standard or small car, and 125,000 yen (~US$1,300) for the purchase of a mini or kei vehicle. Subsidies for purchasing trucks and buses meeting the stipulated fuel efficiency and emission criteria vary between 400,000 yen (~US$4,300) to 1,800,000 yen (~US$19,000).<ref name=JAMAFact/><ref name=JAMANews/><ref name=Outlook/>
All incentives for new purchases with or without trading were applicable in Japan's fiscal year 2009, from April 1, 2009 through March 31, 2010.<ref name=JAMANews/><ref name=Outlook>{{cite web|url=http://www.marklines.com/en/rinji/outlookfor2009_sales_en.jsp#japan|title=Sales Promotion Scheme and 2009 Vehicle Sales Forecasts - Japan: Rebate for purchase or replacement with eco-friendly vehicles|publisher=Marklines.com|accessdate=2010-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426043330/http://www.marklines.com/en/rinji/outlookfor2009_sales_en.jsp#japan|archivedate=2009-04-26|df=}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Electric car]] * [[Electric car use by country]] * [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles]] * [[List of modern production plug-in electric vehicles]] * [[New energy vehicles in China]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicle]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in California]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in Canada]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in Europe]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in France]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in Germany]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in the Netherlands]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in Norway]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in Sweden]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in the United Kingdom]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in the United States]] * [[Plug-in hybrid]]

revision.text:
A '''Pump As Turbine''' or '''(PAT)''', otherwise known as a ‘'''Pump in Reverse'''’, is an unconventional type of reaction water turbine, which behaves in a similar manner to that of a [[Francis turbine]]. The function of a PAT is comparable to that of any [[turbine]], to convert kinetic and pressure energy of the fluid into mechanical energy of the runner. They are commonly commercialized as composite pump and motor/generator units, coupled by a fixed shaft to an asynchronous [[induction type motor]] unit.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Agarwal|first1=Tarang|title=Review of pump as turbine (PAT) for micro-hydropower|journal=International Journal of Emerging Technology and Advanced Engineering|date=November 2012|volume=2|issue=11|page=163-169|citeseerx=10.1.1.414.3606}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=A.A.|title=Pumps as turbines for low cost micro hydro power|journal=Renewable Energy|date=September 1996|volume=9|issue=1-4|pages=1227–1234|doi=10.1016/0960-1481(96)88498-9}}</ref>
Unlike other conventional machines which require being manufactured according to the client’s specifications, pumps are a very common piece of equipment widely available in different sizes and functionality anywhere around the globe. When used as a turbine, the rotor moves in the opposite direction, or in reverse, as to when it is operating as a pump. In this manner, it allows the motor may generate electrical power.
== History == First mentions of the possibility of using pumps as turbines (PAT) dates back to the early 1930s and are associated to lab experiments performed by Thoma and Kittredge,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thoma|first1=D|last2=Kittredge|first2=C|title=Centrifugal pumps operated under abnormal conditions|journal=Power|date=1931|page=881–884}}</ref> who first identified the potential for a common pump to function quite efficiently as a turbine by reversing the flow.
Subsequently, in the second half of the 20th century, a new impulse for research on this topic came from the pump manufacturing industry. During this time, established collaborations with several research institutes helped develop an in-depth understanding of the phenomena associated with PAT utilization. Efforts were made to develop methods to predict characteristic and efficiency curves. This helped determine the Best Efficiency Point (BEP) of these machines, in turbine mode, and related it to its specifications when used as a pump.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Singh|first1=Punit|title=Optimization of internal hydraulics and of system design for PUMPS AS TURBINES with field implementation and evaluation|journal=Universität Karlsruhe (TH): Diss. Institut für Wasserwirtschaft und Kulturtechnik|date=2005|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.459.9416}}</ref>
== Theory of operation == {{catmain|Water_turbine#Reaction_turbines}} {{Empty section|date=May 2018}}
== Types == Among the existing designs of hydraulic pumps/PATs, "centrifugal" or "radial" units are the most used worldwide in a wide variety of application fields.<ref name="auto">{{cite book|author=Grundfos Industry|title=Pump Handbook|date=2004|url=http://noteswww.grundfos.com/web/homeind.nsf/Grafikopslag/handbookPDF/$file/Pump_handbook_industry.pdf}}</ref> The name is derived from the radial path followed by the fluid in the rotor: from the centre to the periphery when running as a pump and in the opposite direction when flow is reversed.<ref name="auto1">{{cite book|last1=Ramos|first1=Helena|title=Guidelines for Design of Small Hydropower Plants|date=2000|url=http://www.civil.ist.utl.pt/~didia/FCT2009/book-SHP.pdf}}</ref> To achieve a higher [[head drop]] across the machine, more [[impeller]]s can be assembled in series to create a multistage unit. Conversely, a double flow radially split pump/PAT design involves a single radial open rotor fed by two symmetric inlets and enable processing a higher flow rate with respect to a standard radial unit.<ref name="auto"/> A second type of pump/PAT design is the axial one, in which the fluid interacts with a propeller following a trajectory parallel to the pump axis. Such units are particularly suitable to processing high flow rates with low head difference. Finally, mixed flow pumps/PATs stand in between the applicability range of radial and axial units and have an impeller shaped in a similar way as a Francis turbine.<ref name="auto1"/> Another special pump/PAT design is that of submersible units, which can possibly be fitted inside a pipe connected to draft tube exploiting small head differences in flowing rivers.
== Typical application chart ==
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Pumps]] [[Category:Turbines]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Robert Ulanowicz |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|9|17|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Baltimore| Baltimore, Maryland]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Gainesville, Florida]] |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |fields = {{plainlist| * [[Theoretical ecology]] * [[Thermodynamics]] }} |workplaces = [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] [[University of Florida]] |alma_mater = [[Johns Hopkins University]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = 2007 [[Ilya Prigogine]] Medal |signature = <!--(filename only)--> |footnotes = }}
'''Robert Edward Ulanowicz''' is an American [[theoretical ecology|theoretical ecologist]] and [[philosopher]] of [[Poles|Polish]] descent who in his search for a ''unified theory of ecology'' has formulated a paradigm he calls ''Process Ecology''.<ref>"Who's Who in Polish America" 1st Edition 1996-1997, Boleslaw Wierzbianski editor; Bicentennial Publishing Corporation, New York, NY, 1996.</ref> He was born September 17, 1943 in [[Baltimore]], Maryland.
He served as Professor of Theoretical Ecology at the [[University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science]]'s [[Chesapeake Biological Laboratory]] in [[Solomons, Maryland]] until his retirement in 2008. Ulanowicz received both his BS and PhD in [[chemical engineering]] from [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1964 and 1968, respectively.
Ulanowicz currently resides in [[Gainesville, Florida]], where he holds a Courtesy Professorship in the Department of Biology at the [[University of Florida]]. Since relocating to Florida, Ulanowicz has served as a scientific advisor to the [[Howard T. Odum]] Florida Springs Institute, an organization dedicated to the preservation and welfare of Florida's natural [[Spring (hydrosphere)|springs]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://floridaspringsinstitute.org/board-of-directors |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-05-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402043550/http://floridaspringsinstitute.org/board-of-directors |archive-date=2016-04-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Overview== Ulanowicz uses techniques from [[information theory]] and [[thermodynamics]] to study the organization of flows of energy and nutrients within ecosystems. Although his ideas have been primarily applied in ecology, many of his concepts are abstract and have been applied to other areas in which [[flow network]]s arise, such as [[psychology]] and [[economics]].
Though Ulanowicz began his career modeling ecological systems using differential equations, he soon reached the limits of this approach.<ref>Mann, K.H., T.C. Platt and R.E Ulanowicz, (eds) 1981, ''Mathematical Models in Biological Oceanography'', UNESCO Monographs on Oceanographic Methodology, 7 UNESCO Press, Paris, 157 p.</ref> Realizing that any ecosystem is a [[complex system]], he decided to move away from what he saw as the inappropriate use of the [[reductionism|reductionist]] approach, and instead began to work towards development of theoretical measures of the ecosystem as a whole, such as [[ascendency]]. Gradually, he came to appreciate the ecosystem behavior is not simply a matter of "mechanics with noise," but rather an intricate interplay between opposing tendencies—autocatalytic-like self-organization and entropic decay. This natural conversation could be followed quantitatively using information-theoretic measures applies to networks of trophic processes.
Following [[Gregory Bateson]], Ulanowicz points out how ecology differs significantly from [[physics]] in that constraints that are absent play important roles in ecosystem dynamics. He also argues how the homogeneous laws of physics only constrain the behavior of very heterogeneous ecosystems but are incapable by themselves of determining outcomes. He goes so far as to suggest that an entirely new metaphysics, which he calls ''Process Ecology'', is required to understand complex living systems.<ref>Ulanowicz, Robert E. "Process Ecology: Making Room for Creation." ''Sophia'' (2016): 1-24.</ref>
One pertinent discovery by Ulanowicz was that ecosystems do not progress to maximum efficiency. Ecosystems that channel too much activity along the most efficient pathways do so at the expense of redundant, less-efficient processes that can function to take over vital activities in the event that mainstream processes are distributed. Ecosystems that persist are those that achieve a balance between the mutually exclusive attributes of efficiency and reliability.<ref>Ulanowicz, R.E. 2009. "The dual nature of ecosystem dynamics ''Ecological Modeling'' 220: 1886-1892.</ref> This result from nature poses a significant challenge to mainstream economics, wherein market efficiency is held to be the ''sine qua non''.<ref>Goerner, S.J., Lietaer, B., and Ulanowicz, R.E. 2009. "Quantifying economic sustainability: Implications for free-enterprise theory, policy, and practice." ''Ecological Economics'' 69:76-81.</ref>
==Publications== Ulanowicz has authored or co-authored over two hundred articles in theoretical ecology and related areas of philosophy, especially those dealing with [[autocatalysis]] and [[causality]]. He has authored three books to date.<ref>[http://www.mdsg.umd.edu/CQ/V04N3/side4/ Profile: A Scientist for All Seasons] Chesapeake Quarterly, Vol. 4, No. 3</ref>
*''A Third Window: Natural Life Beyond Newton and Darwin'', Templeton Foundation Press (2009) ({{ISBN|159947154X}})--A description of Ulanowicz's new metaphysics *''Ecology: The Ascendant Perspective'', Columbia University Press (1997) ({{ISBN|0231108281}}) - Causality in living systems, written for a more general audience *''Growth and Development - Ecosystems phenomenology'', Springer (1986) ({{ISBN|0387962654}}) - A more technical exposition of Ulanowicz's early ideas
==Palms==
While living in Maryland, Ulanowicz took up a hobby of cultivating and casually breeding cold-hardy palm trees; he drew attention for a [[Windmill palm]] on [[Solomons, Maryland|Solomons Island]] that grew taller than the one-story building it was planted outside.<ref>[http://ww2.somdnews.com/stories/102506/recfea163931_32093.shtml Erica Mitrano, "Palm gracing Solomons conjures a tropical breeze", ''Southern Maryland Newspapers Online'', Oct. 25, 2006.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326094505/http://ww2.somdnews.com/stories/102506/recfea163931_32093.shtml |date=2012-03-26 }}</ref>
==Awards== Ulanowicz was named the recipient of the 2007 [[Ilya Prigogine]] Medal for outstanding research in ecological systems.<ref>[http://www.wessex.ac.uk/conferences/2007/eco07/ ECOSUD 2007: Sixth International Conference on Ecosystems and Sustainable Development] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007164714/http://www.wessex.ac.uk/conferences/2007/eco07/ |date=2007-10-07 }}</ref> He participated in the [[Stock Exchange of Visions]] project in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stockexchangeofvisions.org/speaker.php?id=49 |title=Robert E. Ulanowicz, Ecologist |publisher=Stock Exchange of Visions |date= |accessdate=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Ulanowicz was a featured speaker at the 2009 Ill STOQ International Conference entitled "Biological Evolution: Facts and Theories," which discussed the impacts and effects of the publication of ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' by [[Charles Darwin]].<ref>{{cite web|author=by rankup |url=http://www.evolution-rome2009.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56&Itemid=58&lang=en |title=自分を信じて転職サイトを使おう – 転職サイトを使う前に自分には能力がないなんて思わないで |publisher=Evolution-rome2009.net |date= |accessdate=2018-08-16}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of American philosophers]] *[[Ascendency]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://cbl.umces.edu/~ulan/ Robert E. Ulanowicz's Home Page] *[http://www.stockexchangeofvisions.org/speaker.php?id=49 Stock Exchange Of Visions: Visions of Robert E. Ulanowicz (Video Interviews)] *[http://isol.alachuaclerk.org/ Alachua County Clerk of Courts]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox pipeline | name = Sandpiper pipeline | type = light [[crude oil]] | photo = | caption = | map = | country = United States | state = | province = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark_region:XX|display=inline,title}} --> | lat = | long = | direction = | start = Beaver Lodge Station, south of [[Tioga, North Dakota]] | through = [[North Dakota]], [[Clearbrook, Minnesota]] and Wisconsin | finish = [[Superior, Wisconsin]] | par = | owner = [[Enbridge Energy Partners]], L.P. | partners = Williston Basin Pipe Line LLC, an indirect subsidiary of Marathon Petroleum Corporation. North Dakota Pipeline Company LLC assets, formerly known as [[Enbridge Pipelines]] (North Dakota) LLC | operator = Enbridge Energy Partners | technical_service_provider = | contractors = | construction = | expected = January 2017 | est = | decom = | length_mi = 616 | discharge = | discharge_bbl_d = 0.25 | diameter_mm = | diameter_in = 24 to 30<!--until Clearbrook, 30 from_Clearbrook to Superior--> | pumping_stations_no = | pumping_stations = new pump station and tanks in Clearbrook }} The '''Sandpiper pipeline''' is a {{convert|616|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} underground [[oil pipeline]] project in the United States. It would carry light [[crude oil]] from the [[Bakken formation|Bakken]] oil fields in Northwest [[North Dakota]], through [[Minnesota]], to end in [[Superior, Wisconsin]]. [[Enbridge Energy Partners]], and Williston Basin Pipe Line LLC, an indirect subsidiary of [[Marathon Petroleum Corporation]] have been planning the project since 2013. In 2015 Enbridge estimated the pipeline will cost about $2.6 billion.
==History== The Sanpiper pipeline project was made public by the media in 2013, and informational hearings for landowners took place in three North Dakota towns during March 2014. The [[North Dakota Public Service Commission]] approved the pipeline in June 2014.<ref name=NDPUC>[http://www.psc.nd.gov/database/docket_view_list.php?s_dept=PU&s_year_case=13&s_seq_num=848&s_company_name=Enbridge+Pipelines+%28North+Dakota%29+LLC Case #: PU-13-848] North Dakota Public Service Commission, retrieved 23 December 2015</ref> The [[Minnesota Public Utilities Commission]] unanimously approved the Sandpiper pipeline, but its decision was overturned in September 2015.<ref name=garvey/>
In September 2016, [[Enbridge Energy Partners]] announced that due to "extensive and unprecedented [regulatory] delays [which] have plagued the Sandpiper pipeline," they were withdrawing their state application and asking for an end to regulatory proceedings, including work on an environmental-impact statement. An Enbridge spokesperson said that the pipeline may be reconsidered once the oil market rebounds but it was then "outside the company’s current five-year planning horizon".<ref name="Star Tribune">{{cite web | url=http://www.startribune.com/enbridge-energy-pulling-plug-on-sandpiper-pipeline/392082361/ | title=Enbridge Energy pulling plug on Sandpiper pipeline | publisher=Star Tribune | date=September 2, 2016 | accessdate=31 October 2016 | author=Hughlett, Mike}}</ref>
==Purpose== In 2015, Enbridge stated that "The Sandpiper Pipeline serves the oil conducting needs of North Dakota residents, which constitutes a public benefit". Per Enbridge, the Sandpiper pipeline represents a "public use", a "statutorily defined public utility.", and its route was chosen with the "greatest public benefit and the least private injury." and "As long as the public benefit can be demonstrated, it is immaterial that private interests are also served." <ref>John Hageman [http://www.grandforksherald.com/news/3814192-gf-county-landowner-plans-appeal-pipeline-decisionGF County landowner plans to appeal pipeline decision. Grand Fork Herald, 9 August 2015, retrieved 23 December 2015]</ref>
Per Enbridge, the pipeline is necessary "to meet demand for Bakken oil".<ref name=kare/> The corporation projects economic benefits of $69 million in property tax revenue for the 3 states, and 3000 construction jobs for workers in Minnesota and North Dakota.<ref name=beast/>
==Description==
The pipeline would enter Minnesota just south of [[Grand Forks, North Dakota]], east to [[Clearbrook, Minnesota|Clearbrook]] Enbridge's terminal. and then south toward Park Rapids along an existing crude oil corridor. Afterwards, the pipeline would run in a transmission line corridor to [[Superior, Wisconsin]].<ref name=kare>Greg Vandegrift [http://www.kare11.com/story/news/2015/02/10/sandpiper-oil-pipeline-minnesota/23173281/ Sandpiper oil pipeline divides Minnesota] Kare11, TEGNA, 10 February 2015</ref>
The route passes through 28 rivers, including the [[Mississippi River]] headwaters, and lakes and wetlands that can’t be reached by nearby roads if a spill should occur.<ref name="Star Tribune">{{cite web | url=http://www.startribune.com/enbridge-energy-pulling-plug-on-sandpiper-pipeline/392082361/ | title=Enbridge Energy pulling plug on Sandpiper pipeline | publisher=Star Tribune | date=September 2, 2016 | accessdate=31 October 2016 | author=Hughlett, Mike}}</ref>
===North Dakota portion=== Informational hearings for landowners took place in three North Dakota towns during March 2014. The [[North Dakota Public Service Commission]] approved the pipeline on 25 June 2014.<ref name=NDPUC/>
Enbridge sued a couple in Grand Forks in 2014, because they refused to give Enbridge an easement and right-of-way. the couple quoted NDPL's abuse of eminent domain, continued reliance on fossil fuels their effect on the environment and possibility for spills as arguments. In August 2015 the couple agreed on an easement, and forfeited compensation, in order to file an appeal to the North Dakota Supreme Court.<ref>John Hageman [http://www.grandforksherald.com/news/local/3815600-watch-now-jury-trial-avoided-grand-forks-sandpiper-pipeline-case Jury trial avoided in Grand Forks Sandpiper Pipeline case.] Grand Forks Herald 11 August 2015</ref>
===Minnesota portion=== In November 2013, Enbridge applied at the [[Minnesota Public Utilities Commission]] (MPUC). The MPUC unanimously approved the project, allowing to do an environmental review later. In September 2015, the {[[Minnesota Court of Appeals]] overruled the PUC decision as a violation of state law.<ref name=garvey/>
In a November 2014 Star Tribune commentary a Polk County commissioner, a Clearwater County commissioner and a Red Lake County commissioner opined, that the Sandpiper pipeline was the "best choice for the state...better than trucks or rail and also offer[ing] economic benefits."<ref>Warren Strandell, Duane Hayes and John Lerohl [http://www.startribune.com/sandpiper-pipeline-is-best-choice-for-state/283548741/ Sandpiper pipeline is best choice for state] Star Tribune, November 23, 2014, retrieved 23 December 2015</ref>
In February 2015, the [[White Earth Indian Reservation]], represented by [[Winona LaDuke]] stated that the pipeline would cross a portion of its land, which Enbridge disputes. La Duke has been against the pipeline because it would violate Indian sovereignty and for environmental reasons.<ref name=beast>Justin Glawe [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/02/02/the-pipeline-fight-pitting-native-americans-against-big-oil.html The Pipeline Fight Pitting Native Americans Against Big Oil] The Daily Beast, 2 February 2015, retrieved 23 December 2015</ref>
The President of [[North America's Building Trades Unions]] came out in a December 2015 commentary criticizing the Minnesota Court of Appeals decision, accused the court was "robbing hard-working Minnesotans of jobs" which would provide workers with a path to middle class.<ref name=garvey>Sean McGarvey [http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/opinion/columns/3900487-labors-view-sandpiper-pipeline-promises-bright-future Labor's view: Sandpiper pipeline promises a bright future], Duluth News Tribune10 December 2015, retrieved 23 December 2015</ref>
==See also== *[[List of oil pipelines#North America|List of oil pipelines in North America]] *[[List of oil refineries]] *[[List of oil spills]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Crude oil pipelines in the United States]] [[Category:Proposed pipelines in the United States]] [[Category:Cancelled energy projects]] [[Category:Enbridge pipelines]]

Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2600:1:C479:FAC1:8C30:3041:1480:12D4|2600:1:C479:FAC1:8C30:3041:1480:12D4]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{dablink|Several terms redirect here. See also [[Top (disambiguation)]], [[Spinning top (disambiguation)]], [[Topspin]]<!--as "top spinning" redirects here-->, and [[The Spinning Topps]].}} {{Expand Portuguese|date=May 2012}} [[File:A tough gang of Spinning Tops.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35||An assortment of spinning tops]] [[File:Die Kinderspiele - Verschiedene Kreisel.jpg|thumb|Extract from ''[[Children's Games (Bruegel)|Children's Games]]'' (1560)]]
A '''spinning top''' is a [[toy]] designed to [[rotation|spin]] rapidly on the ground, the motion of which causes it to remain precisely balanced on its tip because of its [[Inertia#Rotational inertia|rotational inertia]]. Such toys have existed since [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]]. Traditionally tops were constructed of [[wood]], sometimes with an [[iron]] tip, and would be set in motion by aid of a [[twine|string]] or [[rope]] coiled around its axis which, when pulled quickly, caused a rapid unwinding that would set the top in motion. Today they are often built of [[plastic]], and modern materials and manufacturing processes allow tops to be constructed with such precise balance that they can be set in motion by a simple twist of the fingers and twirl of the wrist without need for string or rope.
== Characteristics == [[File:Gyroscope precession.gif |thumb|Japanese Gyro-top (Chikyu Goma) developed by Tiger & Co., Nagoya, Japan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gyro-top to stop: Maker closing shop |date=February 22, 2015 |publisher=The Japan News |url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001953949 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223001126/http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001953949 |archivedate=February 23, 2015 |df= }}{{Subscription required}}</ref>]] {{multiple image | width = 110 | direction = vertical | image1 = Color top 1895.png | image2 = PSM V11 D687 The color top.jpg | footer = Maxwell's color top (1895) and one from ''[[Popular Science Monthly]]'' (1877) }}
The motion of a top is produced in the most simple forms by twirling the stem using the fingers. More sophisticated tops are spun by holding the axis firmly while pulling a string or twisting a stick or pushing an [[auger (drill)|auger]]. In the kinds with an auger, an internal weight rotates, producing an overall circular motion. Some tops can be thrown, while firmly grasping a string that had been tightly wound around the stem, and the [[centrifugal force]] generated by the unwinding motion of the string will set them spinning upon touching ground.
The top is one of the oldest recognizable toys found on [[archaeology|archaeological]] sites. Spinning tops originated independently in cultures all over the world.<ref>{{cite book | author = D. W. Gould | title = The Top | publisher = Clarkson Potter | location = NY |year = 1973 | isbn = 0-517-50416-2}}{{page needed|date=May 2017}}</ref> Besides toys, tops have also historically been used for [[gambling]] and [[prophecy]]. Some [[role-playing game]]s use tops to augment [[dice]] in generating randomized results; it is in this case referred to as a ''spinner''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} A [[thumbtack]] may also be made to spin on the same principles. Gould mentions [[maple]] [[samara (fruit)|seeds]], [[celt (tool)|celts]] (leading to [[rattleback]]s), the [[bow drill|fire-drill]], the [[spindle (textiles)|spindle]] [[spindle whorl|whorl]], and the [[potter's wheel]] as possible predecessors to the top, which he assumes was invented or discovered multiple times in multiple places.<ref>Gould (1973), p.20-4.</ref>
The action of a top is described by equations of [[rigid body dynamics]] (see the section [[rigid body dynamics#Rotation in three dimensions|Rotation in three dimensions]]). Typically the top will at first wobble until the shape of the tip and its interaction with the surface force it upright; contrary to what is sometimes assumed, longstanding scientific studies (and easy experimentations reproducible by anyone) show that less friction increases the time before the upright position is reached (unless the top is so unbalanced that it falls before reaching it).<ref name="Crabtree">{{cite book | author = H. Crabtree | title = An Elementary Treatment of the Theory of Spinning Tops and Gyroscopic Motion | publisher = Longman, Green and C | location = London |year = 1909}}</ref> After spinning upright (in the so-called "sleep" position) for an extended period, the [[angular momentum]] will gradually lessen (mainly due to friction), leading to ever increasing [[precession]], finally causing the top to topple in a frequently violent last thrash. In the "sleep" period, and only in it, provided it is ever reached, less friction means longer "sleep" time (whence the common error that less friction implies longer global spinning time)
There have been many developments within the technology of the top. Bearing tops, with a tip made of a small hard ceramic, tungsten carbide or even ruby ball (sometimes wrongly believed to spin with respect to the body of the top), have been one of the biggest changes. In addition, plastic and metal have largely supplanted the use of wood in tops. Fixed tip tops are featured in National Championships in [[Chico, California]] and in the World Championships in [[Orlando, Florida]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
The following two well-known characteristics of a top that increase its global spinning time (<ref name="Crabtree"/>) are exploited in various ways in such championships and by the main top makers (obviously, an optimisation of both characteristics has to be somehow restricted by conditions on mass and/or diameter and by practical considerations about the rim not touching the spinning surface too early):
- low center of gravity
- high moment of inertia
A top may also be used to demonstrate visual properties, such as by [[James David Forbes]] and [[James Clerk Maxwell]] in Maxwell's disc (see [[color triangle]]). By rapidly spinning the top, Forbes created the illusion of a single color that was a mixture of the primaries:<ref>{{cite book|title=The Natural Philosophy of James Clerk Maxwell|author=Peter Michael Harman|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-00585-X|year=1998|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qf6jtc4nZisC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=forbes+maxwell+color+top|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227210539/https://books.google.com/books?id=qf6jtc4nZisC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=forbes+maxwell+color+top|archivedate=2017-12-27|df=}}</ref>
{{quote|[The] experiments of Professor J. D. Forbes, which I witnessed in 1849… [established] that blue and yellow do not make green, but a pinkish tint, when neither prevails in the combination…[and the] result of mixing yellow and blue was, I believe, not previously known.|James Clerk Maxwell|Experiments on colour, as perceived by the eye, with remarks on colour-blindness (1855), [[Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]]}}
Maxwell took this a step further by using a circular scale around the rim with which to measure the ratios of the primaries, choosing [[vermilion]] (V), [[emerald (color)|emerald]] (EG), and [[ultramarine]] (U).<ref>{{cite book|title=The Scientific Papers of James Clerk Maxwell|author=James Clerk Maxwell|publisher=[[Dover Publications]]|isbn=0-486-49560-4|year=2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=duyKrTNps_AC&pg=PA127&lpg=PA127&dq=maxwell+vermilion+emerald+ultramarine|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227210539/https://books.google.com/books?id=duyKrTNps_AC&pg=PA127&lpg=PA127&dq=maxwell+vermilion+emerald+ultramarine|archivedate=2017-12-27|df=}}</ref>
Asymmetric tops of virtually any shape can also be created and designed to balance.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bächer|first1=Moritz|last2=Whiting|first2=Emily|last3=Bickel|first3=Bernd|last4=Sorkine-Hornung|first4=Olga|title=Spin-It: Optimizing Moment of Inertia for Spinnable Objects|journal=ACM Conference on Computer Graphics & Interactive Techniques ([[SIGGRAPH]]) 2014|date=August 10–14, 2014|url=http://www.disneyresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/Project_SpinIt_SIGGRAPH14_paper.pdf|accessdate=15 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810090719/http://www.disneyresearch.com/wp-content/uploads/Project_SpinIt_SIGGRAPH14_paper.pdf|archivedate=10 August 2014|df=}}</ref>
== Notable types == {{multiple image | width = | direction = vertical | align = right | image1 = Perinola plastico.jpg | caption1 = A cheap plastic version of the Perinola | image2 = Celt with weights of gemstone turtles-01.jpg | caption2 = Carved wooden rattleback }}
Gould lists the six main types of tops as the twirler, supported top, peg-top, whip-top, [[whirligig|buzzer]], and [[yo-yo]].<ref>Gould (1973), p.32.</ref>
* Competing tops ** [[Battling Tops]] ** [[Beigoma]] ** [[Beyblade (toy)|Beyblade]] ** [[Gasing pangkah]] ** [[Spin Fighters]] * Gaming and other tops ** [[Dreidel]] ** [[Bhawra]] ** [[Bambaram]] ** [[Gyroscope]] ** [[Levitron|Levitating top]], based on the interaction between gravitational, electromagnetic and gyroscopic forces (the equilibrium position is hard to find) find) ** '''Bhawra''', a gaming top used in Maharashtra in India. ** '''Perinola''', a six-sided top, very similar to the dreidel, that is used for a similar game in Latin America<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Q0oAAAAMAAJ&q=perinola+top&dq=perinola+top&pgis=1|author=National Recreation Association|page=92|title=Recreation|year=1965|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113192555/http://books.google.com/books?id=4Q0oAAAAMAAJ&q=perinola+top&dq=perinola+top&pgis=1|archivedate=2013-11-13|df=}}</ref> ** [[Rattleback]], or "celt", a top that reverses its spin direction ** [[Teetotum]] ** [[Tippe top]] ** [[Trompo]], or "Whipping top" ** [[Wizzzer]]
== In popular culture == [[File:2447 - Museo archeologico di Milano - Trottola, da Tebtynis, sec. I-III d.C. - Foto Giovanni Dall'Orto, 1 feb 2014.jpg|thumb|Ancient Roman wooden spinning top, from Tebtynis (Egypt), dating from the 1st-3rd century CE.]]
The [[Jean Shepherd]] story "Scut Farkas and the Murderous Mariah" revolves around top-spinning in the fictional Depression-era American city of Hohman, Indiana. The bully and the named top in the title are challenged by Shepherd's ongoing protagonist Ralph and a so-called "gypsy top" of similar design to Mariah named Wolf.<ref>Shepherd, Jean. "Scut Farkas and the Murderous Mariah", ''Wanda Hickey's Night of Golden Memories and Other Disasters'' (New York: Doubleday Dolphin Books), 1976 {{ISBN|0-385-11632-2}}</ref>
[[The Top (short story)|The Top]] is a [[short story]] by [[Czech literature|Czech]] writer [[Franz Kafka]].
== See also == * [[Bauernroulette]] * [[Diabolo]] * [[Fidget spinner]] * [[Gee-haw whammy diddle]] * [[ForeverSpin]] * [[Lagrange, Euler, and Kovalevskaya tops]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == {{Commons|Spinning top}} {{Wikisource1911Enc|Top}} * Crabtree, H. "An Elementary Treatment of the Theory of Spinning Tops and Gyroscopic Motion". Longman, Green and C), 1909. Reprinted by Michigan Historical Reprint Series. * Perry J. "Spinning Tops". London Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1870. Reprinted by Project Gutemberg ebook, 2010. * Provatidis, Christopher, G. (2012). Revisiting the Spinning Top, ''International Journal of Materials and Mechanical Engineering'', Vol. 1, No. 4, pp. 71–88, open access at http://www.ijm-me.org/Download.aspx?ID=2316 (ISSN Online: 2164-280X, ISSN Print: 2162-0695) * A forum discussing all things related to the art of Top Spinning: [http://www.ta0.com/forum/index.php iTopSpin.com] * {{Cite NSRW|wstitle=Top|short=x}}
{{Object manipulation}}
